title: Draft protocol on the application of the Charter of fundamental rights of the European Union to the Czech Republic (consent): RECOMMENDATION on the European Council's proposal not to convene a Convention for the addition of a Protocol on the application of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union to the Czech Republic, to the Treaty on European Union and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union
background: Following the Czech Republic's 2011 request to join Protocol 30 (limiting Charter of Fundamental Rights application, initially applied to Poland and the UK) post-Lisbon Treaty ratification, the European Council proposed amending EU treaties without convening a Convention. The Parliament will discuss procedural compliance and implications of extending Protocol 30 to the Czech Republic.

stances.stance:
EPP fully approves the decision to avoid convening a Convention, perfectly aligning with its commitment to legal coherence by recognizing the Charter's established binding force through prior treaties.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's assessment that Protocol No 30 maintains fundamental rights obligations, reflecting Schöpflin's analysis of its limited legal impact despite political gestures.  
EPP fully supports the conclusion that evolving Czech political dynamics render the Protocol extension unnecessary, in harmony with national parliamentary sovereignty principles.  
EPP endorses the prioritization of EU constitutional integrity, as highlighted by Kolarska-Bobińska's emphasis on equal Charter application across all Member States.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's procedural efficiency, affirming that maintaining existing frameworks avoids redundant institutional processes while upholding citizens' rights.

EFD supports the issue’s recognition of prior Conventions but advises revising Protocol No 30 to extend exemptions to the Czech Republic, preventing ECJ interference in historical property disputes like the Beneš Decrees.  
EFD highlights the need to align Protocol 30’s terms with national sovereignty concerns, proposing amendments to ensure the Charter cannot override settled judicial rulings in member states.  
EFD advises clarifying Protocol 30’s text to explicitly exempt the Czech Republic from Charter applicability in areas affecting post-war legal settlements, mirroring UK and Poland’s initial safeguards.  
EFD expresses concern that without binding exemptions, the ECJ may erode Czech judicial authority, urging procedural adjustments to prevent retrospective challenges to national courts.  
EFD concurs that a new Convention is unnecessary but stresses the urgency of revising existing protocols to address ECJ overreach, as evidenced by the UK’s post-Lisbon experience.

ECR completely endorses the European Council’s proposal to avoid convening a Convention, as this aligns perfectly with their commitment to national sovereignty and streamlined EU decision-making processes.  
ECR emphasizes that the issue’s adherence to existing treaties reinforces their core principle that member states’ legal subjectivity originates from sovereign existence, not supranational institutions.  
ECR proposes enhancing procedural efficiency in parliamentary responses to future agreements to strengthen institutional credibility, reflecting on the delayed formal stance as a procedural refinement opportunity.  
ECR applauds the issue’s clarification that Protocol No 30 maintains fundamental rights obligations, aligning with their stance against exemptions undermining EU legal coherence.  
ECR underscores that rejecting new Conventions advances their priority of curtailing unnecessary EU institutional proliferation, preserving national autonomy in integration matters.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s alignment with ensuring the EU Charter’s full applicability, emphasizing that opt-out clauses like Protocol No 30 undermine fundamental rights protections.  
GUE_NGL advises reinforcing the Charter’s binding status across all member states to prevent future exemptions, citing risks from nationalist movements eroding EU integration.  
GUE_NGL highlights the Czech Senate’s prior opposition and new presidential leadership as evidence that extending Protocol No 30 lacks democratic justification.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending the issue’s preamble to explicitly reject all opt-outs from the Charter, ensuring uniform application of social and civil rights.  
GUE_NGL cautions that while supporting the decision, ongoing vigilance is needed against attempts to dilute the Charter’s enforceability in national contexts.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the European Council’s proposal not to convene a Convention to extend Protocol No 30—which limits the application of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights to Poland and the UK—to the Czech Republic, citing that the Charter’s binding status was established through prior Conventions (1999-2000 and 2002-2003) and the Lisbon Treaty (effective 2009), rendering a new Convention unnecessary. It emphasized that the Charter, originally proclaimed in 2000 and revised in 2007, was integral to the EU’s constitutional framework, and extending the Protocol’s scope to the Czech Republic would have limited legal impact. The resolution noted that Protocol No 30, while addressing specific national concerns, does not exempt states from upholding fundamental rights under EU law. Parliament concluded that the proposal did not warrant a Convention, as it did not alter the Charter’s core applicability, and instructed its President to communicate this decision to EU institutions and national parliaments.

title: Draft protocol on the application of the Charter of fundamental rights of the European Union to the Czech Republic (consultation): REPORT on the draft protocol on the application of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union to the Czech Republic (Article 48(3) of the Treaty on European Union)
background: Following the 2009 European Council agreement to attach a protocol on Charter application to the Czech Republic, the Czech government submitted a 2011 proposal amid domestic constitutional debates and prior parliamentary ratification of the Lisbon Treaty. The Parliament will discuss the draft protocol extending Charter application conditions to the Czech Republic.

stances.stance:
EPP completely supports the issue's conclusion that Protocol No 30 creates legal ambiguity and undermines uniform application of EU fundamental rights protections.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the Court of Justice's authoritative interpretation confirming the Charter's full applicability across all Member States regardless of protocols.  
EPP unequivocally supports maintaining the integrity of the Charter's binding force and rejects any mechanisms implying differentiated rights protection among citizens.  
EPP emphasizes that extending redundant protocols contradicts the Union's foundational principle of ensuring equally visible rights for all, as enshrined in Article 2 TEU.  
EPP applauds the issue's alignment with EPP's 2022 position paper demanding full Charter implementation without national exemptions.

EFD fundamentally disputes with the issue's rejection of Protocol 30 extensions, insisting the Czech Republic requires explicit opt-outs to prevent ECJ interference in national jurisprudence.  
EFD conditionally sanctions concerns about legal fragmentation but demands treaty amendments to exempt all three states from Charter applicability under Title IV provisions.  
EFD opposes the issue's reliance on ECJ interpretations, urging deletion of paragraphs asserting Protocol 30's redundancy given demonstrated judicial overreach post-Lisbon.  
EFD highlights the proposal's failure to address property restitution risks, requiring explicit clauses to shield Beneš Decrees from Charter-based challenges via Article 17(1).  
EFD requests revisions to recognize member states' constitutional primacy, amending recital 9 to delete "undermines uniform rights" and insert "respects national sovereignty thresholds."

GREEN_EFA completely advocates the issue’s rejection of Protocol No 30 as antithetical to universal EU rights, perfectly aligning with their unyielding defense of equal fundamental protections.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s reliance on the ECJ’s 2011 judgment, which confirms the Charter’s binding force and exposes the Protocol’s redundancy as a political ploy.  
GREEN_EFA completely advocates highlighting the Czech Senate’s 2011 opposition, reinforcing their stance that no member state should dilute rights under false “opt-out” pretenses.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with condemning the Protocol’s extension to the Czech Republic as a dangerous precedent, echoing their manifesto commitment to indivisible rights across all EU territories.  
GREEN_EFA completely advocates amplifying civil society objections, viewing this as critical to upholding their principle that rights protections must never be bargained for political expediency.

ECR completely rejects the issue's characterization of Protocol No 30 as creating legal uncertainty, aligning with Vlasák's assertion that sovereign states derive legal authority from their existence rather than EU frameworks.  
ECR rejects the issue's dismissal of national parliamentary ratification processes, reflecting Vlasák's emphasis on EU integration being "primarily a matter for nation states."  
ECR condemns the issue's supranational rights harmonization agenda, echoing Vlasák's warning against "transferring competencies to European quasi-institutions."  
ECR disputes the issue's claims about weakened rights protections, supporting Vlasák's view that delayed EU action demonstrates institutional incapacity rather than constitutional necessity.  
ECR opposes the issue's reliance on ECJ interpretations, consistent with Vlasák's argument that political agreements between member states should prevail over judicial activism.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Czech Republic’s request to join Protocol No 30, which applies the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights to Poland and the UK, emphasizing that the Protocol does not constitute an opt-out but creates legal uncertainty and undermines uniform rights protection across the EU. The resolution highlighted that the European Court of Justice (ECJ) affirmed in its 2011 judgment that Protocol No 30 does not exempt the UK or Poland from the Charter’s binding provisions, clarifying it merely reiterates existing limits on EU competences. The Czech Senate opposed the Protocol in 2011, fearing it would lower fundamental rights protections for Czech citizens, while academic and legal analyses noted the Protocol’s redundancy, as the Charter already respects national constitutional orders and subsidiarity. The Parliament stressed that extending the Protocol to the Czech Republic, driven by political assurances from the 2009 European Council, risks perpetuating confusion and weakening the EU’s commitment to high rights standards. It also noted doubts about the Czech Parliament’s willingness to ratify the Protocol, potential constitutional challenges, and objections from Czech civil society, trade unions, and human rights groups. The resolution concluded that Protocol No 30, if interpreted restrictively, would diminish rights protections in affected states and harm the EU’s goal of ensuring equal, visible fundamental rights for all citizens.

title: Amendment of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union with regard to a stability mechanism for Member States whose currency is the euro: REPORT on the draft European Council decision amending Article 136 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union with regard to a stability mechanism for Member States whose currency is the euro
background: Eurozone sovereign debt crises prompted temporary financial stability mechanisms (EFSF/EFSM) set to expire in 2013, amid concerns over economic instability and currency sustainability. The Parliament will discuss amending TFEU Article 136 to establish a permanent stability mechanism for euro area Member States.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the full integration of the European Stability Mechanism into the EU institutional framework, aligning with its commitment to transparency and democratic accountability through Commission oversight and parliamentary scrutiny.  
EPP approves the issue’s emphasis on favorable lending conditions and back-to-back borrowing costs for ESM beneficiaries, reflecting its priority to prevent unsustainable debt cycles while maintaining fiscal responsibility.  
EPP endorses the inclusion of all Member States regardless of size in the stability mechanism, ensuring cohesion and rejecting fragmentation risks that contradict the principle of a unified European economic space.  
EPP proposes enhancing the ESM’s financing structure by incorporating risk-based contributions to incentivize fiscal discipline, aligning with its broader advocacy for sustainable economic governance and preventive measures.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of leveraging existing EU institutions like the Commission and ECB, reinforcing its longstanding position that Community methods—not intergovernmental shortcuts—ensure durable crisis-issue frameworks.

EFD fully challenges the integration of the ESM into EU structures as an undemocratic power grab lacking public consent, directly contradicting their sovereignty principles.  
EFD rejects the issue's economic governance framework for perpetuating the "disgraceful and fraudulent" euro system causing mass unemployment in southern Europe.  
EFD condemns financial bailouts as enabling structural failures in deficit states rather than enforcing German-style fiscal discipline through market mechanisms.  
EFD disputes all Treaty amendments bypassing national referendums, denouncing this as an "insult to taxpayers" funding southern overspending without reform mandates.  
EFD insists on intergovernmental solutions over EU institutional control, opposing Commission involvement as supranational overreach incompatible with subsidiarity.

SD strongly advocates integrating the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) fully into EU institutional frameworks, aligning with their commitment to transparency and democratic accountability. They propose amending Article 136 TFEU to mandate Commission oversight and eliminate parallel intergovernmental structures.  

SD approves the ESM’s stabilization role but urges leveraging Article 20 TEU to involve non-eurozone states, ensuring solidarity and avoiding fragmentation of the single market.  

SD advocates revising the Treaty under Article 48(6) TEU to formalize the ESM within EU law, emphasizing the need to “recommunitise” monetary policy and reject intergovernmental shortcuts that undermine Lisbon Treaty principles.  

SD highlights the necessity of aligning ESM lending terms with existing EU mechanisms like the Balance-of-Payments Facility, ensuring favorable interest rates and sustainable growth conditionality as outlined in the issue.  

SD emphasizes enhancing parliamentary scrutiny during the European Semester, proposing concrete amendments to strengthen EU-level oversight of ESM conditionality and macroeconomic governance.

GUE/NGL rejects the fast-track Treaty amendment as anti-democratic, firmly conflicting with their demand for Convention-led reforms and public debate on EU economic governance.  
GUE/NGL opposes the ESM’s establishment outside EU structures, highlighting its creation of parallel governance that undermines parliamentary scrutiny and social protections.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue’s alignment with austerity-driven policies, which perpetuate social cuts and violate the party’s commitment to workers’ rights and collective bargaining.  
GUE/NGL denounces the exclusion of national parliaments and citizens from decision-making, viewing this as a consolidation of technocratic control over Member States’ economic sovereignty.  
GUE/NGL warns that the stability mechanism entrenches neoliberal fiscal discipline, directly contradicting their manifesto against EU-imposed macroeconomic straitjackets.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the establishment of the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) outside the EU institutional framework, stressing the need to integrate it fully into Union structures to ensure transparency, democratic accountability, and the involvement of EU institutions like the Commission, ECB, and European Investment Bank. It emphasized that the ESM must respect EU law, avoid creating parallel governance structures, and align with existing mechanisms such as the Balance-of-Payments Facility (BoP) and Macro-financial Assistance (MFA) in terms of lending conditions, including back-to-back borrowing costs and favorable interest rates. The resolution highlighted the importance of strengthening economic governance, including sustainable growth policies, stricter financial regulation, revision of the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP), and addressing macroeconomic imbalances. It urged exploring enhanced cooperation under Article 20 TEU to involve non-eurozone Member States and called for legislative proposals and Treaty revisions under Article 48(6) TEU or ordinary procedures to formalize the ESM within the EU framework. The Parliament also stressed the need for parliamentary scrutiny at both EU and national levels, particularly during the European Semester, to ensure compliance with economic guidelines and conditionality. Additionally, it advocated for a consolidated Eurobonds market and warned against fragmenting the euro area by excluding smaller economies from the ESM. The resolution reaffirmed the exceptional nature of Article 48(6) TEU revisions and Parliament’s right to demand a Convention for broader institutional reforms.

title: Elections to the European Parliament in 2014: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the elections to the European Parliament in 2014
background: The 2009 Lisbon Treaty's institutional reforms, ongoing Eurozone crisis pressures, and declining voter turnout in prior European Parliament elections framed preparations for the 2014 elections as the first post-Lisbon vote. The Parliament will discuss electoral procedures and measures to strengthen EU governance legitimacy through the 2014 elections.

stances.stance:
EPP supports aligning the Commission President’s election with parliamentary outcomes, emphasizing European political parties’ role in fostering citizen engagement through EU-focused campaigns.  
EPP advises verifying whether the proposed May election dates optimize voter turnout, suggesting flexibility to avoid conflicts with national electoral calendars.  
EPP endorses gender balance in the College of Commissioners but underscores the need to prioritize merit alongside diversity in candidate selection.  
EPP stresses the importance of maintaining a clear link between electoral results and the European Council’s proposal for Commission President, respecting Parliament’s democratic mandate.  
EPP calls for enhanced public communication to clarify how the 2014 electoral reforms strengthen citizens’ direct influence over EU leadership choices.

GREEN_EFA supports the issue’s emphasis on linking Commission President selection to electoral outcomes, aligning with their vision for democratically accountable EU leadership.  
GREEN_EFA advises amending the gender balance clause to include binding quotas for Commissioner portfolios, ensuring measurable progress toward parity.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening Article 6 by requiring the European Council to publicly justify any deviation from nominating the lead candidate of the winning political group.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need for explicit safeguards against national agenda dominance in campaigns, urging penalties for parties failing to prioritize EU-level platforms.  
GREEN_EFA endorses parliamentary oversight of the Commission but suggests codifying MEPs’ right to initiate no-confidence votes against individual Commissioners.

ALDE supports the issue’s emphasis on linking Commission President elections to parliamentary results, aligning with ALDE’s federalist vision for democratic accountability.  
ALDE advises strengthening provisions for European political parties to organize transnational debates between Commission President candidates, enhancing public engagement.  
ALDE recommends amending gender balance requirements to include binding quotas for Commissioner nominations, ensuring substantive equality over symbolic gestures.  
ALDE highlights concerns about ambiguity in the European Council’s obligation to reflect electoral outcomes, urging stricter adherence to Parliament’s mandate.  
ALDE suggests synchronizing election dates across all member states to amplify media impact and voter participation.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's top-down approach to nominating the Commission President, arguing it perpetuates the EU's democratic deficit by prioritizing elite consensus over genuine citizen engagement.  
GUE_NGL opposes the failure to mandate proportional representation in Member States' electoral systems, asserting that excluding political minorities contradicts fundamental democratic principles.  
GUE_NGL entirely rejects with the issue's emphasis on presidential personalization, advocating instead for structural reforms that empower grassroots movements and parliamentary accountability.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of democratic legitimacy by not requiring binding mechanisms to ensure the Commission President reflects electoral outcomes beyond superficial party nominations.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's inadequate measures to address systemic exclusion, reiterating that "no taxation without representation" must apply to all EU citizens through equitable political participation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of enhancing democratic legitimacy by aligning the election of the Commission President with the outcomes of the European Parliament elections, urging European political parties to nominate candidates for this role and ensure their active participation in electoral campaigns. It emphasized the need for the European Council to propose a Commission President candidate reflecting electoral results, with Parliament electing the President in July 2014 to allow sufficient preparation time for the new Commission to assume office by 1 November 2014. The resolution called for gender balance within the College of Commissioners and requested the Council to consult Parliament on scheduling the 2014 elections for either 15–18 May or 22–25 May. It reiterated the Commission’s accountability to Parliament and stressed the role of European political parties in fostering citizen engagement, while affirming Parliament’s authority to approve the entire Commission following hearings with candidate Commissioners proposed by the Council and President-elect.

title: Composition of the European Parliament with a view to the 2014 elections: REPORT on the composition of the European Parliament with a view to the 2014 elections
background: The impending 2014 European elections, Croatia's accession to the EU, and the expiration of transitional provisions under Protocol No 36 and the Croatian Accession Act necessitated adjustments to parliamentary seat allocation. The Parliament will discuss establishing a composition framework for the 2014-2019 term, balancing demographic shifts and institutional representation under Treaty obligations.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the issue's balanced application of degressive proportionality, ensuring smaller states retain political weight while respecting demographic realities.  
EPP approves the pragmatic cap limiting seat losses to one per member state, preventing disproportionate impacts during Croatia's accession transition.  
EPP emphasizes the urgency of adopting this interim solution to maintain electoral preparedness, aligning with EPP's institutional stability priorities.  
EPP proposes accelerating development of the 2015 permanent apportionment system to include binding mathematical criteria, enhancing predictability for future enlargements.  
EPP commends the linkage between parliamentary representation reforms and Council voting weight revisions, advancing federal balance as core to EU integration.

ALDE strongly agrees the adoption of a degressive proportionality principle to balance demographic accuracy with equitable citizen representation, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to transparent and mathematically grounded EU institutional reforms.  
ALDE approves the pragmatic limitation of seat losses to one per member state, ensuring Council unanimity while advancing Croatia’s integration, a measure reflecting ALDE’s priority of operational cohesion amid enlargement.  
ALDE proposes strengthening future apportionment by embedding the Cambridge compromise formula into the 2015 Convention agenda to minimize arbitrary adjustments and institutionalize objective demographic criteria.  
ALDE highlights the critical linkage between Parliament seat allocation and Council voting weight reforms, urging synchronized Treaty revisions under Article 48(3) TEU to achieve holistic democratic parity.  
ALDE endorses the committee’s adjustment preserving Sweden’s seats as a fair application of degressive proportionality, ensuring Swedish citizens avoid underrepresentation relative to comparable member states.

ECR strongly accepts the pragmatic seat allocation compromise, recognizing its necessity to meet electoral deadlines while maintaining degressive proportionality as required by EU treaties.  
ECR proposes refining future apportionment formulas to better correlate MEP ratios with population size, addressing disparities like the UK-Germany representation gap noted in Article 14(2) TEU implementation.  
ECR emphasizes the urgency of addressing emigration-driven demographic shifts in the 2015 reform package to prevent underrepresentation of states losing populations to intra-EU mobility.  
ECR approves linking Parliament composition reforms to broader Council voting revisions, aligning with their commitment to dual citizen-state representation principles under Article 48(3) TEU.  
ECR highlights the importance of capping seat reductions at one per state as a vital safeguard against destabilizing abrupt changes to national representation.

GUE_NGL rejects the degressive proportionality model as absolutely disputeing with their commitment to equal representation among sovereign EU states, disproportionately penalizing smaller nations like Portugal.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue’s failure to address democratic deficits, arguing that reduced seats for medium/small states erode pluralism and distance citizens from EU decision-making.  
GUE_NGL condemns the rushed adoption process for prioritizing institutional convenience over meaningful public engagement, overlooking citizen skepticism toward EU centralization.  
GUE_NGL highlights contradictions with subsidiarity principles, noting the issue ignores proposals to strengthen the Committee of the Regions and local governance frameworks.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally disputes the federalist power balance embedded in the seat allocation, which entrenches large-state dominance in both Parliament and Council.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to establish the composition of the European Parliament for the 2014-2019 term, proposing a decision based on Article 14(2) TEU and accounting for Croatia’s accession, which would adjust seat allocations to reflect demographic changes while ensuring degressive proportionality—where more populous states receive more seats but each member represents more citizens than in less populous states. It emphasized urgency in adopting the decision to allow member states to prepare for the 2014 elections, limiting seat losses to a maximum of one per state to balance adjustments. The resolution committed to proposing a durable, transparent apportionment system by 2015, incorporating objective criteria, demographic trends, and potential transnational lists, to be implemented ahead of the 2019-2024 term. It linked this reform to broader institutional changes, including revising Council voting systems through Treaty revisions under Article 48(3) TEU, stressing the dual representation of citizens and member states as foundational to EU democracy. The Parliament also noted the expiration of Protocol No 36 and Croatia’s accession-related provisions at the end of the 2009-2014 term, underscoring the need for timely action to align institutional frameworks with evolving membership and population dynamics.

title: Conclusions of the informal European Council meeting of 30 January 2012: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the European Council of 30 January 2012
background: Persistent eurozone debt crisis pressures and divergent national fiscal policies prompted EU leaders to negotiate enhanced economic governance, culminating in the January 2012 European Council's draft Treaty on Stability, Coordination, and Governance. The Parliament will discuss the treaty's implications for fiscal discipline mechanisms, economic policy coordination, and growth strategies within EMU frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the fiscal treaty's emphasis on budgetary discipline and structural reforms, aligning with their commitment to economic stability and sustainable growth.  
EPP approves the integration of parliamentary proposals into the treaty framework, particularly upholding the Community method and legal accountability through ECJ oversight.  
EPP urges accelerated implementation of growth initiatives, including establishing a redemption fund and advancing project bonds to complement fiscal consolidation.  
EPP emphasizes completing the single market and enforcing existing rules to enhance competitiveness, in line with their economic policy priorities.  
EPP proposes ensuring full parliamentary participation in euro summit meetings to strengthen democratic oversight while maintaining treaty ratification timelines.

EFD rejects the Treaty on Stability as a colonial imposition that humiliates sovereign states, directly contradicting Farage’s condemnation of “diplomacy at gunpoint” toward Greece.  
EFD opposes fiscal integration measures for perpetuating German-dominated austerity, aligning with Tzavela’s warning about a “teenage hegemonist” divide eroding European unity.  
EFD absolutely disputes with the issue’s growth agenda, citing Farage’s argument that euro membership causes catastrophic unemployment and social desperation.  
EFD condemns the undemocratic exclusion of parliaments from euro summits, mirroring Tzavela’s criticism of procedures circumventing democratic accountability.  
EFD disputes the issue’s solidarity claims, highlighting Farage’s and Tzavela’s warnings about resurgent nationalism fueled by EU-imposed economic subjugation.

SD strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on integrating the fiscal compact into EU law, aligning with their commitment to preserving the Community method and democratic accountability.  
SD approves the call for binding growth measures like redemption funds and project bonds, which directly advance their priorities for sustainable investment and social solidarity.  
SD highlights the need to strengthen youth employment targets through enforceable EU-wide programs, enhancing the treaty’s social dimension while maintaining fiscal responsibility.  
SD proposes accelerating the implementation of a robust Financial Transaction Tax to generate resources for growth initiatives, ensuring balanced economic recovery.  
SD emphasizes full parliamentary inclusion in Euro summits as critical to upholding institutional legitimacy, urging treaty revisions to formalize this role.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the Fiscal Compact Treaty's austerity framework as it conflicts with their mandate for social equity and sustainable growth initiatives.  
GUE_NGL opposes the undemocratic imposition of budgetary sovereignty loss through reversed qualified majority voting and ECJ penalties, contrary to their constitutional self-determination principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s failure to address speculative capital flows and tax havens, core drivers of inequality explicitly denounced in João Ferreira’s critique.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s contradiction with SME-reported priorities by prioritizing wage cuts over credit access and customer demand solutions as noted by Marisa Matias.  
GUE_NGL demands treaty rejection for institutionalizing IMF-style conditionalities that exacerbate crises, aligning with Søren Bo Søndergaard’s condemnation of fines-as-policy irrationality.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the Treaty on Stability, Coordination, and Governance in the Economic and Monetary Union, reiterating its preference for achieving reforms within existing EU law rather than through an intergovernmental agreement, which was necessitated by the UK Prime Minister’s objection. While acknowledging improvements in the final text, including the incorporation of parliamentary proposals such as upholding the Community method, it noted that key elements like the fiscal "golden rule," reversed qualified majority voting, and ECJ involvement could not be fully realized under current EU frameworks. The resolution emphasized that fiscal stability must be paired with concrete measures to boost sustainable growth, employment, and solidarity, urging rapid establishment of a redemption fund based on the German Economic Council’s proposal, integration of project bonds, a roadmap for stability bonds, and implementation of a European Financial Transaction Tax. It criticized omissions in the treaty, particularly the lack of full parliamentary participation in euro summit meetings, and insisted on integrating the treaty into EU law within five years while addressing remaining weaknesses in the Lisbon Treaty. The Parliament also called for stronger Commission action on growth initiatives and expressed regret over delays in advancing these measures through the "two-pack" legislative process.

title: Forwarding to and handling by the European Parliament of classified information held by the Council on matters other than those in the area of the Common Foreign and Security Policy: REPORT on the conclusion of an interinstitutional agreement between the European Parliament and the Council concerning the forwarding to and handling by the European Parliament of classified information held by the Council on matters other than those in the area of the common foreign and security policy
background: Existing EU transparency rules and the Parliament’s legislative oversight role under the Lisbon Treaty necessitated structured access to classified Council documents outside foreign and security policy. The Parliament will discuss finalizing an interinstitutional agreement governing the exchange and handling of such classified information between the institutions.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the interinstitutional agreement as a critical advancement of democratic scrutiny, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to transparency and Treaty-based institutional cooperation.  
EPP applauds the mature framework for accessing classified information, which effectively advances EPP's priority of informed parliamentary oversight while respecting necessary confidentiality protocols.  
EPP emphasizes the urgency of implementing robust internal systems to operationalize the agreement, ensuring Parliament can fully exercise its enhanced oversight capabilities without delay.  
EPP proposes strengthening future negotiations on Common Foreign and Security Policy matters by replicating this agreement's cooperative spirit to close remaining transparency gaps.  
EPP highlights the agreement's alignment with Lisbon Treaty principles, particularly Article 15 TFEU, as a model for sincere interinstitutional collaboration in security-sensitive domains.

ALDE strongly approves the issue’s foundation in transparency principles, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to open governance and Article 15 TFEU’s mandate for institutional accountability.  
ALDE approves the codification of parliamentary access rights to classified information as crucial for effective oversight, effectively advancing ALDE’s priority of balancing security protocols with democratic scrutiny.  
ALDE emphasizes the need for future interinstitutional agreements to harmonize document access rules across all EU bodies, ensuring equal transparency standards for the Council, Commission, and Parliament.  
ALDE proposes enhancing the agreement by incorporating a binding commitment in Article 9 to initiate negotiations on extending classified information protocols to Common Foreign and Security Policy matters within 12 months of ratification.  
ALDE applauds the alignment with Regulation 1049/2001’s Articles 2(5) and 9, which reinforce Parliament’s role in scrutinizing EU actions while maintaining confidentiality, as a critical step toward institutional parity.

SD strongly advocates the establishment of clear procedures for accessing classified information, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to institutional transparency under TEU Article 10.  
SD approves the expanded access for rapporteurs and committee members as vital for fulfilling Parliament’s oversight role, consistent with Regulation 1049/2001’s Article 2(5) principles.  
SD highlights the agreement’s progress in reducing security clearance requirements for non-CFSP matters as a meaningful enhancement of democratic accountability.  
SD proposes strengthening future protocols to address CFSP-related information access with equal rigor, ensuring parity in scrutiny mechanisms across policy areas.  
SD emphasizes that the issue’s balance between confidentiality and parliamentary oversight effectively advances their 2011 transparency demands from paragraph 12.

ECR strongly promotes the interinstitutional agreement as achieving a necessary balance between parliamentary transparency and legitimate confidentiality requirements for member states. This aligns perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to accountable governance while respecting national sovereignty.  
ECR approves the alignment of Council information-sharing protocols with existing Commission procedures, ensuring consistent standards for democratic oversight across EU institutions.  
ECR highlights the agreement’s enhancement of scrutiny capabilities for budgetary and legislative matters as critical to advancing their priority of rigorous EU expenditure oversight.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for enhanced transparency and accountability in handling classified information between EU institutions, emphasizing the importance of public access to documents as enshrined in Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001, particularly Articles 2(5) and 9. It called for an interinstitutional agreement with the Council to establish clear procedures for forwarding and managing classified information on non-common foreign and security policy matters, ensuring Parliament’s right to access such information for effective democratic oversight. The resolution underscored the legal basis provided by the Treaties (TEU Articles 1, 2, 6, 10, 11 and TFEU Articles 15, 295), which mandate openness and institutional balance. It reiterated concerns from its 2011 resolution on public access to documents, specifically paragraph 12, urging alignment of classified information protocols with transparency principles. The Parliament stressed that any agreement must safeguard its role in scrutinizing EU actions while maintaining necessary confidentiality, balancing security requirements with democratic accountability.

title: Citizens’ initiative: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the citizens' initiative
background: The Treaty of Lisbon (2009) introduced a citizens’ initiative mechanism under Article 11(4) TEU, enabling EU citizens to request legislative proposals. The European Commission’s 2010 draft regulation aimed to operationalize this provision. The Parliament will discuss establishing procedural rules for the initiative’s implementation, ensuring alignment with treaty obligations and citizen engagement frameworks.

stances.stance:
EFD partially endorses the citizens' initiative framework but emphasizes the need to prevent EU institutions from exceeding Treaty mandates.  
EFD requests revisions to include robust signature verification mechanisms, citing risks of fraudulent submissions undermining democratic legitimacy.  
EFD highlights concerns that the issue fails to address sufficient safeguards against bureaucratic overreach in the admissibility process.  
EFD stresses the initiative must remain strictly limited to EU citizens, opposing any expansion to non-citizen participation.  
EFD notes the proposal's democratic improvements but maintains it remains inconsistent with their principles of national sovereignty in legislative matters.

GREEN_EFA completely agrees the issue’s procedural cooperation framework, perfectly aligning with their commitment to participatory democracy under Article 11(4) TEU.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the retention of digital signature provisions as critical for modernizing civic engagement, reflecting their digital governance priorities.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need to transform institutional distrust into proactive trust-building measures, urging accelerated implementation of citizen-led policy channels.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the issue’s alignment with legislative transparency demands, effectively advancing their manifesto goals for interinstitutional accountability.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the outcome as a milestone in direct democracy, directly enabling citizens’ creative contributions as envisioned in their 2024 Action Plan.

ALDE absolutely endorses the citizens’ initiative regulation as a landmark achievement in perfect alignment with their foundational principles of participatory democracy and institutional transparency, particularly through binding public hearings upon million-signature thresholds.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s strict adherence to Treaty frameworks, emphasizing that Article 2’s replication of Article 11(4) TEU empowers citizens to directly shape treaty evolution within legal boundaries.  
ALDE celebrates the initiative’s capacity to institutionalize grassroots political innovation, bridging EU policymaking with digital-era civic engagement as envisioned in Europe 2020’s deliberative democracy goals.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s procedural rigor in ensuring Commission accountability, requiring exhaustive justification for rejected initiatives while maintaining Parliament’s colegislative oversight via Treaty Article 294 TFEU.  
ALDE recognizes the citizens’ initiative as a transformative mechanism for regional advocacy, enabling substate entities to bypass institutional marginalization by directly channeling proposals to EU decision-makers.

GUE_NGL supports the issue's advancement of participatory democracy but advises expanding signature eligibility to include all EU residents through Amendments 71-74.

GUE_NGL acknowledges procedural improvements in the regulation while emphasizing the need for binding commitments to reassess implementation after three years.  
GUE_NGL advises reinforcing youth engagement mechanisms to ensure broader democratic participation beyond current citizenship requirements.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting the resolution at first reading, emphasizing procedural cooperation with EU institutions and member states. It endorsed the Commission’s original proposal (COM(2010)0119) while urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or alternative texts are proposed, ensuring legislative transparency. The resolution highlighted alignment with Treaty provisions, particularly Article 11(4) TEU on participatory democracy and Article 294 TFEU governing the ordinary legislative procedure. It incorporated input from committees, including Constitutional Affairs, Petitions, Culture and Education, and Civil Liberties, reflecting cross-sectoral priorities. Parliament instructed its President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional dialogue and adherence to EU legislative protocols.

title: European Parliament's right of inquiry: REPORT on a proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament on the detailed provisions governing the exercise of the European Parliament's right of inquiry  and repealing Decision 95/167/EC, Euratom, ECSC of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission
background: The Lisbon Treaty (2009) granted the European Parliament treaty-based authority to establish inquiry committees, but existing rules under a 1995 decision lacked alignment with updated institutional roles. The Parliament will discuss modernizing procedures for committees investigating alleged maladministration in EU law implementation under its supervisory mandate.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA totally promotes the issue's immediate audit mandate and expenditure reporting requirements, perfectly aligning with their commitment to exposing financial misconduct and ensuring citizen-level accountability.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the independent review panel provision, recognizing its necessity to enforce consequences for non-cooperation and fraud as emphasized in the debate.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports the centralized transparency portal, effectively advancing their decades-long advocacy for public access to scrutinize EU fund allocation.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the misused funds reallocation to climate action, reflecting their core principle of prioritizing ecological transition over bureaucratic waste.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s streamlined administrative procedures, which mirror their manifesto pledge to eliminate redundant costs while strengthening oversight.

ALDE applauds the independent review panel’s establishment as a critical step to combat financial mismanagement, matching their manifesto priorities for institutional integrity.  
ALDE endorses the centralized public data portal, effectively advancing their longstanding advocacy for accessible transparency to strengthen public trust.  
ALDE proposes amending inquiry procedures to clarify distinct scrutiny roles for EU and national officials, ensuring political oversight without conflating administrative hierarchies.  
ALDE strongly promotes reallocating misused funds to climate and digital initiatives, reflecting their policy focus on sustainable and technological progress.

SD strongly accepts the issue’s emphasis on stricter oversight mechanisms, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to transparency and accountability in EU fund management.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the financial mismanagement and lack of transparency in the allocation of funds under Article 22 of the EU budget, emphasizing the need for stricter oversight mechanisms to prevent misuse of public resources. The resolution called for an immediate audit of all projects funded under Article 22 since 2020, prioritizing those exceeding €5 million, and mandated that member states submit detailed expenditure reports by June 2025. It highlighted that 30% of reviewed projects failed to meet predefined performance indicators, urging the reallocation of unspent or misused funds to climate action and digital transition initiatives. Additionally, the Parliament demanded the establishment of an independent review panel to assess compliance with anti-fraud regulations and recommended reducing administrative costs by 15% by 2027 through streamlined procedures. The resolution also stressed the importance of enhancing public access to project data via a centralized portal to ensure accountability.

title: Decision not to convene a Convention for the revision of the Treaties with regard to transitional measures concerning the composition of the European Parliament: RECOMMENDATION on the European Council’s proposal not to convene a Convention for the revision of the Treaties with regard to transitional measures concerning the composition of the European Parliament
background: The Lisbon Treaty's 2009 entry into force altered European Parliament composition rules, but pre-Treaty June 2009 elections under Nice Treaty provisions resulted in 736 MEPs conflicting with Lisbon’s 751-seat limit. The European Council proposed revising Protocol No. 36 to address transitional membership adjustments. The Parliament will discuss procedural requirements for Treaty amendments regarding EP composition.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the expedited amendment process through an intergovernmental conference, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to efficient EU institutional functionality and democratic legitimacy.  
EPP approves the transitional measures' swift implementation to ensure full parliamentary representation, effectively advancing their priority of balanced multinational participation in decision-making.  
EPP applauds the issue's pragmatic alignment with Lisbon Treaty protocols, mirroring their 2009 institutional reform strategies to maintain legislative continuity.  
EPP proposes future treaty revisions to harmonize electoral procedures across Member States, enhancing predictability while fully endorsing the current limited-scope solution.  
EPP emphasizes the critical importance of simultaneous MEP integration to uphold the European Parliament's operational credibility and proportional nationality representation.

GREEN_EFA rejects fundamentally the intergovernmental revision process as a violation of the Treaty requirement for direct election of MEPs, conflicting with their core democratic principles.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the "French exception" allowing appointed parliamentarians, which undermines 31 years of EU suffrage standards central to their legitimacy doctrine.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's failure to convene a Convention, directly contradicting their constitutionalist stance on participatory Treaty reforms beyond governmental bargaining.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the acceptance of nationally appointed MEPs as eroding Parliament's credibility and citizens' right to choose representatives through elections.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal's incompatibility with Article 48(3) TEU procedural safeguards against unilateral Member State interference in electoral integrity.

SD approves utilizing an intergovernmental conference rather than full Convention procedures, recognizing the protocol's temporary nature while maintaining procedural continuity under Article 48(3).

GUE_NGL rejects the Treaty revision shortcut as a dangerous departure from 2007 precedents requiring immediate elections for new member states' MEPs, creating an undemocratic double standard.

GUE_NGL asserts this decision normalizes backroom treaty amendments, directly conflicting with their 2024 manifesto commitment to "defend transparent constitutionalism against elite power grabs."

resolution: The European Parliament raised support for amending Protocol No 36 on transitional measures under the Lisbon Treaty, which entered into force on 1 December 2009, to address the composition of Parliament. It acknowledged the historical significance of the 2002-2003 Convention drafting the EU Constitution (later integrated into the Lisbon Treaty) and the 1999-2000 Convention drafting the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, both advancing democratic decision-making. The resolution endorsed the European Council’s proposal to bypass convening a new Convention for this limited-scope amendment, deeming it unnecessary given the transitional nature of the protocol’s provisions. It approved revising the protocol through an intergovernmental conference instead, emphasizing alignment with prior institutional reforms from European Council meetings in 2008-2009. The Parliament instructed its President to communicate this decision to the European Council, Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity under Article 48(3) of the EU Treaty.

title: Location of the seats of the European Union's institutions: REPORT on the location of the seats of the European Union’s Institutions
background: The EU Parliament's seat locations, established by Member States via treaties, involve Strasbourg, Brussels, and Luxembourg, with evolving legislative authority increasing operational demands. Concerns over financial, environmental, and efficiency impacts of multiple locations, alongside citizen petitions, prompted review. The Parliament will discuss institutional seat allocation and self-determination authority regarding its working arrangements.

stances.stance:
EPP partly upholds the need for operational efficiency but insists any Treaty revision must precede seat changes, citing Protocol 6's explicit Strasbourg designation as non-negotiable without full intergovernmental consensus.  
EPP requests revised financial analysis using Parliament Secretariat's verified €51.5 million Strasbourg cost estimates rather than "unsubstantiated" €156-204 million figures in the issue.  
EPP demands removal of petition references until identity-validated signatures meet Article 227 TFEU standards, rejecting the "1.2 million citizen" claim as procedurally invalid.  
EPP requires broader institutional seat review encompassing ECB and CJEU locations before Parliament-specific changes, per Constance Le Grip's polycentrism principle.  
EPP proposes maintaining Strasbourg's symbolic role through annual plenary sessions if reforms proceed, preserving its status as "democracy's birthplace" while reducing logistical burdens.

EFD supports the issue’s emphasis on ending wasteful relocation practices, aligning with their core principle of fiscal responsibility and reducing EU bureaucracy.  
EFD advises amending Protocol 6 to allow repurposing Strasbourg’s facilities for the Committee of the Regions and Economic and Social Committee, ensuring continued local economic activity without parliamentary presence.  
EFD highlights the 1.3 million citizen petitions as critical evidence that maintaining multiple seats erodes public trust, reinforcing the need for urgent Treaty revision.  
EFD suggests prioritizing Brussels as the sole legislative hub to strengthen collaboration with other institutions, while retaining Strasbourg for symbolic plenary sessions to address French concerns.  
EFD raises concern that the issue’s transitional period for building reallocation lacks concrete deadlines, risking prolonged inefficiencies unless binding timelines are added.

ALDE strongly sanctions the issue's call for Parliament's autonomy in determining its seat, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to institutional efficiency and citizen-centric governance.  
ALDE approves the emphasis on resolving the democratic imbalance caused by Protocol 6, which prioritizes member states over citizens’ representation in seat allocation.  
ALDE highlights the report’s principled focus on self-organization rather than preemptively favoring specific locations, thereby advancing ALDE’s priority of pragmatic EU reform.  
ALDE proposes clarifying the procedural roadmap for Treaty revision under Article 48 TEU as a technical enhancement to expedite implementation.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s alignment with their manifesto goals to prioritize functional decision-making over fragmented national interests.

ECR strongly endorses the issue’s demand to end the Strasbourg seat arrangement, aligning perfectly with ECR’s longstanding commitment to fiscal responsibility and streamlined governance.  
ECR approves the call for Treaty revision under Article 48 TEU, emphasizing how this advances ECR’s priority of institutional accountability and citizen-centric decision-making.  
ECR highlights the environmental urgency of eliminating 19,000 tonnes of CO₂ emissions through a single seat, reinforcing ECR’s environmental stewardship principles.  
ECR proposes accelerating the 2014 Eurobarometer survey deadline to expedite public mandate validation, enhancing democratic transparency without opposing the issue’s core aims.  
ECR applauds the issue’s alignment with citizen demands for cost-efficiency, mirroring ECR’s manifesto pledge to combat bureaucratic waste in EU structures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the inefficiency, high costs, and environmental impact of maintaining three separate workplaces in Strasbourg, Brussels, and Luxembourg, as mandated by Protocol 6 of the EU Treaties. It highlighted annual costs between €156 million and €204 million (10% of its budget) and CO₂ emissions of 11,000–19,000 tonnes due to monthly relocations, with Strasbourg’s buildings unused 89% of the year. Emphasizing its evolution into a co-legislator with increased legislative activity (454 ordinary procedures in 2004–2009 versus 165 in 1993–1999), Parliament argued that its dispersion isolates it from other EU institutions and stakeholders, undermining efficiency and transparency. It noted strong public opposition, including a petition signed by over one million citizens, and a 2012 plenary vote where 78% of MEPs supported revising the seat arrangement. Parliament called for a Treaty revision under Article 48 TEU to amend Article 341 TFEU and Protocol 6, enabling it to determine its own seat and working arrangements. It requested independent analyses of potential savings from a single seat (Brussels) and a Eurobarometer survey by 2014 on citizens’ views, while acknowledging the need for orderly transition and continued use of existing buildings. The resolution stressed the urgency of addressing this issue during the financial crisis and reaffirmed Parliament’s commitment to cost-efficiency, environmental responsibility, and democratic accountability.

title:
Report: Elmar Brok - The institutional aspects of setting up the European External Action Service
on the institutional aspects of setting up the European External Action Service: REPORT on the institutional aspects of setting up the European External Action Service
background: The European Union's expanding global role and the Treaty of Lisbon's provisions for a unified external action framework, following its ratification process including the 2009 Irish referendum, necessitated institutional reforms. The Parliament will discuss establishing the European External Action Service to enhance diplomatic coherence and operational efficiency under the treaty's legal structure.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the establishment of the EEAS as a vital mechanism for coherent EU foreign policy, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to institutional integration and global strategic influence.  
EPP approves the EEAS’s sui generis structure within the Commission’s administrative framework, effectively advancing their priority of upholding the Community method while ensuring accountability to Parliament and Council.  
EPP emphasizes the imperative of geographical balance and merit-based staffing in the EEAS, resonating with their manifesto pledge to ensure equitable representation for all Member States, particularly newer ones.  
EPP proposes augmenting the European diplomatic college initiative by integrating established national training centers like Bruges and Natolin to leverage existing expertise without duplicating resources.  
EPP highlights the critical role of parliamentary scrutiny in budgetary and appointment processes, urging enhanced transparency through renegotiated interinstitutional agreements to strengthen democratic oversight.

ALDE strongly agrees the establishment of the EEAS as a transformative tool for EU foreign policy coherence, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to supranational efficiency and global strategic influence through integrated diplomatic structures.  
ALDE approves the EEAS's hybrid accountability framework under the Commission's administrative oversight, emphasizing its critical role in maintaining parliamentary scrutiny and financial transparency as outlined in Articles 18 and 27 of the Treaty on European Union.  
ALDE endorses the issue's call for a European diplomatic college, proposing enhanced collaboration with national foreign ministries to standardize training in consular procedures and crisis management while preserving member states' operational flexibility.  
ALDE emphasizes the need to prioritize soft security mechanisms within the EEAS mandate, advocating for explicit integration of development cooperation and humanitarian aid as core instruments to advance the EU's peacebuilding objectives globally.  
ALDE highlights the importance of equitable staffing practices in EEAS delegations, urging proactive measures to ensure smaller member states' diplomatic expertise informs decision-making without compromising operational cohesion.

ECR rejects the establishment of a European diplomatic college as fiscally irresponsible and incompatible with national sovereignty, absolutely doubting with ECR's principle of resisting EU power consolidation over member states' foreign policy prerogatives.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the EEAS mission nomenclature proposals, demanding explicit rejection of "embassies" terminology which contradicts ECR's red line against EU state-like attributes in international affairs.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of intergovernmental accountability by seeking Commission-aligned structures rather than maintaining strict Council authority over EEAS operations, violating ECR's anti-federalist governance model.  
ECR challenges the issue's assumption of CFSP unanimity erosion, opposing any EEAS evolution that could bypass member states' veto rights under Article 24 TEU through bureaucratic practice.  
The budgetary provisions for EEAS institutional growth directly conflict with ECR's fiscal conservatism, demanding strict reliance on seconded national diplomats rather than creating permanent EU diplomatic corps.

GUE/NGL rejects the militarization framework enabling EEAS crisis management units as completely conflicting with anti-militarist principles.  
GUE/NGL opposes the Lisbon Treaty's institutional model for creating undemocratic structures that bypass national sovereignty and economic justice priorities.  
GUE/NGL condemns the exclusion of parliamentary oversight in EEAS negotiations, which overlooks critical transparency demands in security policy formation.  
GUE/NGL disputes the intelligence-sharing provisions as enabling military agendas inconsistent with diplomatic conflict issue commitments.  
GUE/NGL challenges the prioritization of foreign policy mechanisms over urgent economic interventions to address unemployment and recession crises.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for a coherent, consistent, and efficient EU foreign policy through the establishment of the European External Action Service (EEAS) under the Lisbon Treaty, emphasizing its role in enhancing the EU’s global visibility, avoiding duplication of resources, and strengthening partnerships with developing nations. The resolution highlighted the EEAS’s legal basis in Articles 18, 27, and 40 of the Treaty on European Union, stressing its sui generis structure as integrated into the Commission’s administrative framework while remaining accountable to both the Council in foreign policy matters and the Commission in external relations. It called for the EEAS to ensure alignment with the Charter of Fundamental Rights and consistency across EU policies under Article 21(3) of the Treaty, while EU delegations in third countries should operate under the authority of the High Representative/Vice-President (VP/HR) and provide logistical support to EU institutions. The Parliament urged the VP/HR to engage with parliamentary committees on senior EEAS appointments, renegotiate interinstitutional agreements for transparency and access to sensitive information, and establish a European diplomatic college to standardize training in diplomacy, consular procedures, and EU affairs. It emphasized a gradual, experience-based evolution of the EEAS, backed by a review clause to ensure fair representation of member states and avoid inefficiencies, while welcoming the Lisbon Treaty’s institutional reforms, including the VP/HR’s role in leading the EU’s Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP).

title: Interinstitutional agreement on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management: REPORT on conclusion of an interinstitutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management
background: Following the Treaty of Lisbon's expanded budgetary role for the European Parliament and protracted 2013 negotiations on the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, including European Council agreements amid post-crisis fiscal constraints, the Parliament will discuss formalizing interinstitutional arrangements for budgetary governance, cooperation mechanisms, and compliance with EU financial regulations.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely promotes the interinstitutional agreement as the only viable path forward under exceptional circumstances, perfectly aligning with their commitment to EU stability through guaranteed 2013 payments and continuity of cohesion policies.  
EPP emphasizes the critical achievement of launching the high-level group on own resources, proposing strengthened financial autonomy mechanisms to address future crises while maintaining current budgetary discipline.  
EPP highlights the issue's enhanced flexibility provisions between commitment appropriations and payment ceilings as essential for efficient crisis response, matching their manifesto priorities for adaptive governance.  
EPP recognizes the mid-term review clause as pivotal for future-proofing EU finances, urging accelerated timelines for reforming revenue streams to prevent structural deficits in Treaty-implemented policies.  
EPP applauds the preservation of key investment programs like Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ within constrained parameters, aligning perfectly with their innovation-driven growth agenda despite overall MFF reductions.

GREEN_EFA denounces the lack of binding financial transaction tax provisions, rendering the agreement inconsistent with their core agenda to regulate markets and fund climate policies.

GUE_NGL rejects the MFF's nominal budget reduction as incompatible with urgent crisis recovery needs, particularly denouncing disproportionate impacts on cohesion funding.  
This proposal overlooks critical aspects of democratic accountability by codifying the European Council's overreach into legislative budgetary matters.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to reverse binding austerity criteria imposed through European Council conclusions, perpetuating harmful macroeconomic conditionality.  
The agreement's institutionalization of growth-stifling financial constraints fully conflicts with GUE_NGL's anti-austerity platform and EU solidarity principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised acceptance of the political agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2014-2020 and a new interinstitutional agreement aimed at enhancing budgetary discipline, flexibility, and cooperation, while criticizing the unsatisfactory implementation of Treaty of Lisbon provisions that granted Parliament greater budgetary and legislative powers. It denounced the Council’s reliance on binding European Council conclusions from February 2013, which imposed constraints on negotiations, including detailed program allocations and financial criteria under the ordinary legislative procedure, thereby undermining Parliament’s role. The resolution expressed regret that years of interinstitutional dialogue failed to influence the Council’s approach or separate legislative and budgetary aspects of the MFF. It concluded that future MFF negotiations require revised working arrangements under Article 312(5) TFEU to ensure full respect for Parliament’s prerogatives, prevent the European Council from overstepping its non-legislative role, and guarantee transparent, democratic processes. Parliament tasked its Committees on Budgets and Constitutional Affairs to propose reforms ahead of the 2016 post-electoral MFF revision, emphasizing the need to address institutional imbalances and strengthen procedural integrity in budget-setting.

title: Interinstitutional agreement on the transparency register: REPORT on the modification of the interinstitutional agreement on the Transparency Register
background: The European Parliament previously established a voluntary Transparency Register (2011) under EU treaty obligations for institutional dialogue transparency, amid concerns over lobbying influence gaps and inconsistent sector participation. The Parliament will discuss revising the interinstitutional agreement to strengthen the register’s framework for monitoring interest representation in EU policy-making.

EPP proposes extending transparency scrutiny to NGOs’ funding sources, ensuring alignment with the issue’s goal of holistic accountability beyond direct lobbying actors.  
EPP emphasizes the constructive role of transparent stakeholder engagement in refining legislation, as exemplified by successful dialogues on data protection reforms.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the enhanced client disclosure requirements for law firms as a critical step toward lobbying transparency, aligning with their manifesto commitment to eradicate opaque influence networks.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the Council’s new observer role in the Register but urges binding treaty reforms to mandate its full participation, addressing democratic deficits in EU decision-making.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the issue’s emphasis on Secretariat verification powers while proposing future measures to penalize non-compliant lobbyists through financial sanctions rather than mere access revocation.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need to extend transparency obligations to national-level lobbying activities revealed in cases like CO2/automotive policy interventions, requiring post-2017 review mechanisms.  
GREEN_EFA welcomes annual progress evaluations but insists these must quantify unreported lobbying via third-party audits to fully assess the Register’s effectiveness.

SD strongly promotes the mandatory transparency register as a critical measure to prevent conflicts of interest and ensure democratic oversight, aligning with their 2008 issue for compulsory lobbying registration.  
SD approves the inclusion of law firms in disclosure requirements, emphasizing the need for full client transparency in financial market lobbying activities to address hidden influence.  
SD urges accelerated timelines for the Council’s full participation in the Transparency Register, enhancing interinstitutional accountability beyond its current observer status.  
SD advocates for robust civil society engagement in annual progress reviews, ensuring continuous public consultation aligns with treaty obligations for open dialogue.  
SD endorses strict prohibitions on external funding for MEPs’ staff as essential to maintaining institutional integrity, reflecting their commitment to eliminating lobbying abuses.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the lack of a mandatory Transparency Register for lobbying activities at EU institutions, reiterating its longstanding call for compulsory registration as outlined in its 2008 resolution and 2011 decision. While acknowledging the partial progress of proposed modifications to the 2011 Agreement, it urged the Commission to propose binding legislation by the end of 2016 under Article 352 TFEU and to seek treaty reforms enabling a mandatory register via ordinary legislative procedures. The resolution emphasized enhancing transparency by requiring law firms and lobbyists to disclose all clients linked to EU policy activities, clarifying exceptions for legal professions, and addressing potential abuses of national rules obstructing transparency. It called for robust civil society involvement in future reviews, a public consultation before the next review, and a comprehensive evaluation by 2017. The Parliament welcomed the Council’s observer role but pressed for its full participation in the Register, alongside improved Secretariat resources to verify data, handle complaints, and implement incentives for registration. It endorsed measures to prevent conflicts of interest, including banning MEPs from external funding for staff and restricting former MEPs’ access to parliamentary premises when lobbying. Annual progress reports on the Register’s coverage and enforcement were mandated, with final approval of the modified Agreement and its publication in the Official Journal.

title: Political parties at European level and rules regarding their funding: REPORT on the application of Regulation (EC) No 2004/2003 on the regulations governing political parties at European level and the rules regarding their funding
background: The Treaty of Lisbon and EU regulations established legal frameworks for European political parties' role in integration and funding mechanisms, with subsequent amendments addressing foundations. SD perfectly aligns with the proposal to streamline funding procedures and reduce bureaucratic hurdles, as this advances SD's priority of empowering European parties to foster integration and amplify citizen engagement through direct membership and transparent operations.

ECR opposes allowing EU-funded parties to intervene in national referendum campaigns, viewing this as an erosion of Member State autonomy over domestic democratic processes.
