ECR rejects lowering self-financing requirements for parties, arguing this entrenches reliance on EU institutions rather than fostering genuine citizen-led financial support.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of subsidiarity, contradicting ECR's core principle that democratic legitimacy flows exclusively from nation-states, not EU-level bureaucracies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to strengthen the role of European political parties and their foundations as vital instruments of EU democracy, emphasizing their role in shaping political will, fostering integration, and enhancing citizen engagement. It highlighted the 2007 amending Regulation, which enabled funding for election campaigns (excluding direct support to national parties) and sought organizational convergence between parties and foundations while preserving their autonomy. The resolution noted structural challenges, including excessive administrative costs (50% of budgets for parties, 40% for foundations) and limited financial autonomy, with less than 5% of party income from individual donations. It called for a common EU legal statute to grant parties direct legal personality, streamline funding procedures, and reduce bureaucratic hurdles, proposing full upfront annual funding (100% instead of 80%) and lowering self-financing requirements to 10% of total budgets for parties (abolishing it for foundations). The Parliament urged raising donation limits to €25,000 per donor annually (with transparency safeguards), allowing parties to engage in EU-related referendum campaigns, and encouraging direct individual membership. It stressed the need for sanctions for funding violations and requested the Commission to propose a tailored Financial Regulation title for party funding, alongside transnational electoral reforms. The resolution also emphasized aligning party operations across regional, national, and EU levels to strengthen democratic accountability and responsiveness.

title: Practical arrangements for the holding of the European elections in 2014: REPORT on improving the practical arrangements for the holding of the European elections in 2014
background: The 2014 European elections, the first post-Lisbon Treaty granting Parliament enhanced powers over Commission appointments, faced declining voter turnout, fragmented national campaign frameworks, and limited visibility of EU political parties. The Parliament will discuss measures to strengthen electoral transparency, pan-European political engagement, and institutional legitimacy ahead of the elections.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the nomination of Commission presidential candidates by European parties, aligning with their commitment to enhancing democratic legitimacy and fostering a pan-European political mandate.  
EPP applauds the emphasis on displaying European party affiliations and emblems on ballots, which directly advances their priority of strengthening citizens' sense of European identity and political belonging.  
EPP endorses the synchronization of election dates and result announcements across all Member States, recognizing this as a critical step in reinforcing the collective European electoral process.  
EPP proposes clarifying the implementation timeline for candidate announcements to ensure uniform readiness, enhancing the issue's effectiveness without opposing its core principles.  
EPP highlights the necessity of public debates between Commission presidential candidates as a vital mechanism to elevate EU-wide political engagement and voter awareness.

EFD rejects the imposition of pan-European party logos on UK ballots as a deceptive attempt to manufacture artificial EU political identity, completely rejecting with EFD's defense of national electoral sovereignty.  
EFD opposes fundamentally the use of British taxpayer funds to finance campaigns under "strange" European party labels like AECR, which lack democratic legitimacy in domestic contexts.  
The proposal's Commission President nomination process disregards British voters' disconnect from EU figureheads, failing to address EFD's core principle of maintaining independent national political systems.  
Mandatory European affiliation displays on ballots directly contradict EFD's position that such requirements erode clarity in national democratic processes.  
The issue's push for EU-wide political broadcasts overlooks critical aspects of national media sovereignty, aligning with EFD's warnings against supranational propaganda mechanisms.

ALDE strongly endorses the inclusion of European party affiliations and emblems on ballots, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to enhancing transnational political identity and voter awareness of pan-European policymaking.  
ALDE approves the mandate for early designation of Commission President candidates, effectively advancing ALDE's priority to elevate European issues over national narratives in election campaigns.  
ALDE endorses gender-balanced candidate lists as a critical step toward ensuring the majority of Europe's population sees its interests represented, mirroring ALDE's 2014 manifesto pledges on equality.  
ALDE proposes strengthening future electoral frameworks by revisiting transnational lists in subsequent reforms, noting their absence as a missed opportunity for deeper political integration.  
ALDE applauds the issue's voter turnout measures and synchronized result announcements, which directly correlate with ALDE's institutional transparency objectives.

ECR rejects the issue's European party affiliation mandates as reinforcing centralized power structures that prioritize financial institutions over national sovereignty.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the Commission President selection mechanism, viewing it as legitimizing anti-austerity policies that have economically devastated member states like Italy and Greece.  
ECR condemns the issue's "European dimension" focus as contradictory to citizens' demands to reclaim decision-making from Brussels-based technocratic elites.  
ECR argues the transparency measures fail to address systemic EU failures evidenced by Italy's disproportionate net contributions and misrepresentation in EU narratives.  
This fully challenges with ECR's position that true democratic legitimacy requires dismantling supranational frameworks rather than expanding Parliament's role post-Lisbon.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to enhance the transparency, democratic legitimacy, and European dimension of the 2014 elections, emphasizing their significance as the first post-Lisbon Treaty elections, which expanded Parliament’s role in electing the Commission President. It called on political parties to publicly announce candidates at least six weeks before polling (22-25 May 2014), ensure gender-balanced candidate lists, and display European party affiliations and emblems on ballots. The resolution urged European parties to nominate Commission presidential candidates early to enable EU-wide campaigns focused on European issues and to hold public debates between candidates. It stressed the importance of democratic candidate selection processes, encouraged national parties to inform voters about their European affiliations and support for Commission candidates, and recommended measures to assist EU citizens voting or standing in other Member States. Parliament urged Member States to boost voter turnout through public campaigns, avoid premature result announcements until all polls closed on 25 May, and align Commission President consultations between Parliament and the European Council. It proposed that the candidate from the European party winning the most seats should be prioritized for securing an absolute parliamentary majority, aiming to strengthen the link between election outcomes and EU leadership.

title: Preparations for the European Council meeting (17 June 2010)-Economic governance: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on EU economic governance
background: Following the 2009 global financial crisis, EU member states faced rising public debt, fiscal imbalances, and market instability, prompting the European Council to initiate deficit reduction procedures and emphasize structural reforms. The Parliament will discuss reforms to EU economic governance frameworks addressing fiscal coordination and crisis response mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue's transformation of economic governance through enhanced Commission authority, perfectly aligning with their commitment to supranational solutions over intergovernmental fragmentation.  
EPP approves the proposed EU Recovery Plan's sustainable investment targets while recommending explicit integration of public-private financing models to amplify infrastructure development efficiency.  
EPP absolutely endorses stricter enforcement mechanisms for the reformed Stability Pact, recognizing this as essential to prevent recurring sovereign debt crises through binding fiscal coordination.  
EPP applauds the issue's emphasis on innovation-driven growth strategies as critical for global competitiveness, matching their 2020 Strategy priorities for digital transformation and research excellence.  
EPP strongly advocates centralized financial market supervision through existing EU institutions, rejecting parallel structures to maintain regulatory coherence across all Member States.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue’s call for an EU Recovery Plan funded by Financial Transaction Taxes and common bonds, aligning perfectly with their commitment to equitable financing and sustainable public investment.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the demand to restructure the Stability and Growth Pact into an Employment and Sustainable Development Pact, effectively advancing their vision of prioritizing social welfare over austerity-driven fiscal consolidation.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the emphasis on democratic legitimacy through parliamentary inclusion, as highlighted by Rebecca Harms, urging enhanced transparency to prevent policymaking in "darkened rooms" and ensure accountability for rescue packages.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening the EU 2020 strategy’s focus on social cohesion and planetary boundaries, echoing Philippe Lamberts’ critique that growth alone cannot address poverty or ecological limits.  
GREEN_EFA approves the issue’s push for stringent financial regulation and public banking control, which directly aligns with their manifesto goals to curb speculative practices and prioritize collective economic stability.

ECR rejects fundamentally the EU Recovery Plan's centralized financial mechanisms as contradictory to member state fiscal sovereignty.  
ECR opposes the proposed Financial Transaction Tax and EU bonds, viewing them as excessive EU-level intervention inconsistent with subsidiarity principles.  
ECR highlights the issue's failure to address Lisbon Strategy failures before launching new programs, mirroring past ineffective "grand schemes".  
ECR condemns restructuring the Stability Pact as regulatory overreach that duplicates existing Member State recovery efforts.  
ECR disputes the €500 billion stabilization mechanism as creating dangerous moral hazard through non-conditional transfers.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the austerity-driven exit strategy as it perpetuates bank-centric rescues while imposing catastrophic social cuts, directly conflicting with their demand for worker-centered crisis issue.  
GUE_NGL opposes the Stability and Growth Pact reforms as "pure sado-monetarism" that accelerates poverty, contradicting their call for an Employment and Sustainable Development Pact with €500 billion stabilization.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s failure to mandate Financial Transaction Taxes or Eurobonds, which they deem essential to fund green/social investments instead of IMF-style wage suppression.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s indifference to 10% EU unemployment and 30% wage collapses in Greece, overlooking their demand for treaty changes to prioritize full employment over monetarism.  
GUE_NGL denounces the lack of binding financial sector dismantling measures, opposing speculative practices they seek to ban through public banking control and capital gains taxation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns that the EU’s post-2009 austerity-driven "exit strategy," mandating deficit cuts below 3% of GDP by 2013/14, risks deepening economic stagnation by undermining social protections, wages, and public investment, thereby reducing demand and tax revenues. It criticized the prioritization of fiscal consolidation and structural reforms, which exacerbate deflationary pressures and social inequality while failing to address public debt, projected to reach 84% of GDP in 2011. The resolution advocated for a three-to-five-year EU Recovery Plan mobilizing 1% of EU GDP annually (approximately €130 billion) to invest in sustainable sectors like renewable energy, public services, green industries, and social welfare, aiming to create decent jobs and combat poverty. It proposed financing this through a Financial Transaction Tax (0.1% rate, generating €262 billion annually), common EU bonds, bank levies, and taxes on capital gains and high incomes, while opposing IMF-style austerity conditions tied to financial assistance. The Parliament urged restructuring the Stability and Growth Pact into an Employment and Sustainable Development Pact, reforming the ECB to prioritize full employment and sustainability, and establishing a €500 billion EU stabilization mechanism without punitive conditionality. Additional measures included tighter financial regulation, bans on speculative practices, public control of banking sectors, and treaty changes to abandon monetarist policies in favor of equitable, growth-oriented governance.

title: Preparations for the European Council meeting (19 - 20 December 2013): MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on preparations for the European Council meeting (19-20 December 2013)
background: Ongoing Eurozone financial instability prompted structural reforms and new economic governance frameworks, while geopolitical shifts including US strategic reorientation and emerging security threats near EU borders highlighted defense capability gaps. The Parliament will discuss completing Banking Union mechanisms, improving economic policy coordination, and strengthening collective defense systems through industrial cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the accelerated implementation of Banking Union mechanisms, particularly endorsing the Single Resolution Mechanism as critical for financial stability  
EPP strongly endorses permanent structured cooperation in defense through NATO-complementary initiatives and industrial standardization to maintain strategic autonomy  
EPP fully backs the creation of a Council of Defence Ministers while proposing enhanced interparliamentary coordination mechanisms for national defense oversight  
EPP strongly approves convergence partnerships for economic governance reform, highlighting emerging recovery signs from coordinated fiscal discipline  
EPP emphasizes urgent defense capability pooling through EU battle groups and ATHENA program optimization to address neighborhood security crises

SD strongly endorses the Banking Union completion, proposing accelerated timelines for the Single Resolution Fund's full capitalization to address concerns about delayed implementation.  
SD approves EMU reform targets but urges binding social convergence indicators to prevent austerity-driven policies conflicting with issue goals.  
SD endorses permanent structured defence cooperation, recommending accelerated CSDP integration through Article 44 implementation before 2015 review deadlines.  
SD aligns with social investment priorities, advocating reallocation of bank fines to Youth Guarantee programs as raised in debate critiques of unemployment.  
SD emphasizes democratic oversight in Banking Union governance, requiring parliamentary scrutiny of issue mechanisms to enhance legitimacy.

ECR rejects the issue's push for EU defence autonomy as completely againsting with NATO's proven transatlantic security framework  
ECR opposes creating EU military structures as duplicative bureaucracy that drains resources from NATO-aligned national defence capabilities  
ECR challenges the assumption that EU "strategic autonomy" can replace US security guarantees given Europe's inadequate defence spending levels  
ECR condemns attempts to establish permanent EU operational headquarters as incompatible with national sovereignty over armed forces  
ECR insists any defence industrial coordination must explicitly subordinate to NATO standards rather than create parallel EU systems

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the issue's militarization agenda, which prioritizes arms industry lobbying over disarmament and peacebuilding efforts mandated by the Nobel Peace Prize legacy.  
GUE_NGL opposes the Banking Union framework and EMU reforms as mechanisms to institutionalize austerity policies that devastate Greek households through electricity cuts, mass unemployment, and reversed social conquests.  
GUE_NGL condemns the proposed defence spending increases as catastrophic misallocation when 26 billion euros annually could instead reverse healthcare/education cuts and address 1.5 million unemployed in Greece alone.  
GUE_NGL denounces the issue's alignment with financial elites through permanent Troika-style surveillance mechanisms like convergence partnerships and post-programme monitoring that erase national sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to address wealth inequality acceleration, where German export surpluses directly correlate with Southern Europe's debt crises through imposed internal devaluations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to finalize the Banking Union by establishing the Single Resolution Mechanism and concluding negotiations on the Deposit Guarantee Directive and recovery framework by the end of 2013. It emphasized deepening the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) through enhanced economic policy coordination, including legislative preparation of "convergence guidelines" with urgent reform targets, adoption of national reform programs by member states’ parliaments, and conditional funding via "convergence partnerships" integrated into the EU budget outside multiannual financial framework ceilings. The resolution stressed integrating the Treaty on Stability, Coordination and Governance into EU law by 1 January 2018 and ensuring EMU reforms promote unity, inclusivity for non-euro states, and adherence to EU law. On defence, it called for strategic autonomy amid geopolitical shifts, addressing uncoordinated defence spending cuts, and accelerating cooperation through Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) reforms, including permanent structured cooperation, enhanced defence industrial coordination, a "European Semester" for defence planning, and leveraging EU instruments like the European Defence Agency. It urged implementing Lisbon Treaty tools, adopting a strategic roadmap (White Book), and reviewing progress by December 2015 based on 2013 Council conclusions. The resolution highlighted the EU’s comprehensive approach to crisis management and supported creating a Council of Defence Ministers to strengthen policy coherence.

title: Preparations for the European Council meeting (27-28 June 2013) - Democratic decision making in the future EMU: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on strengthening European democracy in the future EMU
background: Persistent eurozone instability, high youth unemployment, and fragmented banking systems underscored institutional challenges in Economic and Monetary Union governance, prompting calls for enhanced structural reforms and economic policy coordination. The Parliament will discuss reinforcing democratic accountability and institutional frameworks within the EMU to address crisis response and integration sustainability.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the issue's demand for urgent Banking Union implementation, aligning with their commitment to financial stability through unified supervision and issue mechanisms.  
EPP absolutely upholds integrating the fiscal compact into EU law within five years, emphasizing this matches their manifesto priorities for binding economic governance.  
EPP proposes enhancing flexibility within the European Semester framework to better address unforeseen crises like natural disasters while maintaining fiscal discipline.  
EPP approves reinforcing the Commission's treaty-based role as guardian of EU law, rejecting intergovernmental shortcuts that undermine institutional balance.  
EPP emphasizes accelerating SME financing solutions through EIB instruments, directly supporting youth employment programs and regional cohesion priorities.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue's insistence on governing the EMU through the Community method, aligning perfectly with their commitment to supranational democracy and rejecting intergovernmental shortcuts that erode institutional balance.  
GREEN_EFA approves the demand to integrate the fiscal compact into EU law but proposes shortening the timeline from five to three years to prevent prolonged austerity dominance.  
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses establishing a full Banking Union, condemning Franco-German attempts to dilute its scope as deepening both financial fragmentation and the EU’s democratic deficit.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of troika accountability reforms, citing the undemocratic closure of Greek public broadcasting as evidence requiring immediate transparency safeguards in EU crisis governance.  
GREEN_EFA advocates expanding the European Semester’s convergence code to include binding social investment targets and SME-focused financial instruments like structured covered bonds.

ECR rejects the issue's centralized governance model as completely rejecting with their core principles of national sovereignty and market freedom, citing the Troika's destructive impact on Greece as evidence of EU institutional overreach.  
ECR opposes integrating the fiscal compact into EU law, arguing this would cement bureaucratic constraints that strangle business growth and contradict their demand for deregulation to combat unemployment.  
ECR dismisses the proposed social pillar and European Semester alignment as socialist policy extensions that replicate France's failed high-tax model, which they blame for 26 million EU unemployed.  
ECR rejects Banking Union expansion and EU-level democratic scrutiny of the ESM, asserting these mechanisms perpetuate financial fragmentation while ignoring root causes like energy price inflation from green regulations.  
ECR totally disapproves the issue's reliance on "Community method" governance, advocating instead for intergovernmental flexibility to let states like Germany independently address labor market needs without EU constraints.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the issue's failure to condemn austerity-driven EMU reforms that exacerbate poverty and social exclusion, directly conflicting with their anti-austerity principles as voiced in critiques of Troika policies in Greece.  
GUE_NGL rejects the fiscal compact integration into EU law as institutionalizing destructive deficit limits, contradicting their demands to end wage suppression and reverse Germany’s "wage dumping" model criticized by Zimmer.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s silence on dissolving Troika structures, which they explicitly denounced for imposing "false data and catastrophic policies" in Greece per Zimmer’s IMF report references.  
GUE_NGL conflicts irreconcilably with the issue’s technocratic "incentive-based mechanisms" that omit binding social progress clauses, disregarding Murphy’s demands to replace austerity with massive public investment for youth employment.  
GUE_NGL dismisses the Banking Union framework for perpetuating financialization without addressing democratic deficits highlighted in their EZB lawsuit critique and Merkel-Hollande intergovernmentalism warnings.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the Council’s lack of ambition and delays in advancing the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU), criticizing national electoral cycles for undermining EU decision-making autonomy and repeated postponements of decisions on EMU architecture. It emphasized the need for democratic accountability, insisting the EMU must be governed via the Community method with full involvement of EU institutions, rejecting intergovernmental approaches and demanding the European Council cease bypassing the Commission’s Treaty-based roles. The resolution called for urgent legislative action to implement the Commission’s 2012 EMU Blueprint, integrate the fiscal compact into EU law within five years, and establish a Banking Union to address financial fragmentation. It stressed the importance of a convergence code under the European Semester, aligned with the Europe 2020 strategy and including a social pillar, supported by incentive-based mechanisms. Parliament demanded the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) be integrated into the EU legal framework under democratic scrutiny, alongside accountability for the EU’s role in the ‘troika’. It reiterated the euro’s status as the Union’s currency and Parliament’s central role in oversight, insisting new EU competences require corresponding democratic control. Finally, it urged the Commission to propose an interinstitutional agreement for Parliament’s involvement in approving the annual growth survey and economic policy guidelines.

title: Preparations for the European Council meeting (27-28 June 2013) - European action to combat youth unemployment: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on preparations for the European Council meeting (27-28 June 2013) – European action to combat youth unemployment
background: By mid-2013, EU youth unemployment exceeded 23%, with over 8 million NEETs and significant economic losses linked to labor market disengagement. Disparities between member states (7.5% in Germany vs. 62.5% in Greece) and sectoral labor shortages persisted despite prior initiatives like the 2011 Youth Opportunities Initiative and 2013 Youth Guarantee recommendations. The Parliament will discuss coordinated EU measures to address youth unemployment and labor market integration.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA absolutely promotes the issue's emphasis on reversing austerity-driven education cuts, perfectly aligning with their commitment to social investment over fiscal consolidation in youth programs.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand for EU-wide social indicators, recognizing this as essential to prevent democratic backsliding like the Greek public broadcasting shutdown they condemned.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely promotes frontloading Youth Employment Initiative funds, mirroring their urgent calls to address southern Europe's 50%+ youth unemployment through immediate liquidity injections.  
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue's dual vocational training focus, seeing this as critical to realizing their Green New Deal job creation targets in ICT and renewable sectors.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with leveraging €60 billion EIB financing for SMEs, directly advancing their advocacy for crowd funding reforms and ethical banking structures.

SD strongly sanctions the Youth Guarantee implementation and frontloaded €6 billion allocation, aligning perfectly with their commitment to urgent social investment while proposing a revision clause to ensure sustained funding flexibility beyond 2015.  
SD strongly endorses education-business partnerships and dual vocational systems as critical for labor market alignment, matching their manifesto priority to combat skill mismatches in ICT and green sectors.  
SD strongly approves leveraging structural funds and EIB financing for youth-focused SMEs, advocating concrete reallocations to meet the ILO’s €21 billion benchmark through cohesion policy reforms.  
SD strongly sanctions condemning austerity cuts to education, emphasizing the issue’s call for social investment in apprenticeships and quality job creation to prevent generational exclusion.  
SD strongly advocates EU-wide social indicators and democratic accountability frameworks, urging explicit safeguards against Troika-imposed service reductions like Greece’s media closures.

ECR rejects the issue's reliance on government-led job creation as totally againsting with their principle that wealth generation stems solely from free markets and deregulation.  
ECR opposes the Youth Guarantee's implementation framework, arguing it overlooks critical aspects like unsustainable public spending and ignores the "legislation that discourages work" through labor protections.  
The proposal's €6 billion allocation for youth employment is deemed inconsistent with ECR's demand to "tear up bureaucracy" rather than "promise unearned benefits passed to future generations."  
ECR condemns the issue's criticism of austerity measures, asserting that "centralised economies have failed" and that Spain's VAT hikes exemplify necessary fiscal discipline despite social costs.  
The emphasis on vocational training partnerships is dismissed unless paired with eliminating "form-filling burdens" for SMEs, as highlighted in Ivo Strejček’s critique of EU regulatory strangleholds.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the Youth Employment Initiative's underfunding, citing the ILO's €21 billion minimum requirement as starkly contrasting with the issue's inadequate €6 billion allocation.  
GUE_NGL rejects austerity-driven policies embedded in the issue, condemning their alignment with Troika-mandated cuts that exacerbate poverty and social exclusion, as evidenced by Greece's public sector dismantling.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to address democratic erosion, exemplified by the Council's exclusion of parliamentary oversight and unchecked expansion of intergovernmental power structures.  
GUE_NGL condemns the hypocrisy of promoting "quality frameworks" while endorsing wage-dumping mechanisms like Germany's low-wage labor market, directly contradicting social progress clauses.  
GUE_NGL dismisses the issue's reliance on private-sector partnerships as a diversion from demanding public investment in job creation and reversing austerity's devastation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over alarming youth unemployment rates in the EU, citing 23.5% overall unemployment (with extremes like 62.5% in Greece and 56.4% in Spain) and 8.3 million young people not in employment, education, or training (NEETs), risking a "lost generation." It highlighted the economic cost of youth disengagement, estimated at €153 billion (1.2% of EU GDP) in 2011, and stressed the need for urgent action to address disparities between Member States. The resolution emphasized education and vocational training reforms, particularly dual systems combining academic and practical skills, as critical to improving employability in growing sectors like ICT, green jobs, and healthcare. It endorsed the Youth Guarantee, urging swift implementation to ensure under-25s and recent graduates under 30 receive employment, education, or apprenticeship offers within four months of unemployment or leaving education, while stressing the need for quality frameworks to safeguard working conditions and wages. Financial measures included allocating €6 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative, advocating frontloading funds, and revising the Multiannual Financial Framework to meet the International Labour Organisation’s €21 billion estimate for eurozone implementation. It called for leveraging the European Social Fund (at least 25% of cohesion policy funds), €60 billion from the European Investment Bank, and €16 billion in reallocated structural funds to support youth employment and SMEs. The resolution urged Member States to combat school dropouts (15% leaving without secondary qualifications), promote partnerships between education and businesses, and enhance mobility while addressing brain drain risks. It criticized austerity cuts to education and youth programs, advocating social investment in job creation, apprenticeships, and self-employment support, and called for crisis measures harming youth employment to be reassessed. Finally, it stressed the need for EU-wide social indicators, private sector collaboration, and aligning curricula with labor market demands to ensure sustainable growth and social rights.

title: Presentation of the College of Commissioners: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on election of the Commission
background: Following the delayed formation of the College of Commissioners under the Lisbon Treaty, concerns emerged regarding nomination processes and portfolio allocations during candidate hearings. The Parliament will discuss the election of the Commission, addressing institutional procedures for appointing EU executive leadership and ensuring coherent policy coordination across member states.

stances.stance:
EPP completely conflicts with the issue's transparency allegations, emphasizing the Framework Agreement's provisions for parliamentary access to Commission documents and legislative initiatives  
EPP rejects claims of insufficient candidate evaluations, citing Joseph Daul's praise for Parliament's "exercise of modern democracy" in commissioner hearings  
EPP opposes the characterization of portfolio overlaps as problematic, defending the Lisbon Treaty's institutional balance demonstrated in transport and Galileo project coordination  
EPP dismisses concerns about delayed nominations, highlighting Jacek Saryusz-Wolski's acknowledgment of strengthened parliamentary oversight through special partnership agreements  
EPP objects to the issue's scrutiny limitations narrative, noting PPE members' documented ability to demand policy clarifications on energy security and crisis management

GREEN_EFA rejects fundamentally the issue's silence on internal EU enlargement processes, failing to address independence movements in Wales and Catalonia that demand democratic restructuring.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the absence of bold climate crisis leadership, particularly the lack of mandated financial transaction taxes and unified market supervision as critical to systemic reform.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the incoherent portfolio allocations creating bureaucratic overlaps, directly contradicting demands for streamlined transport and state aid governance.  
GREEN_EFA conflicts with the issue's neglect of proactive EU foreign policy, omitting Barnier-report-aligned disaster prevention mechanisms and assertive Council engagement.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the legal tolerance for extended Commissioner mandates, violating Treaty of Lisbon principles requiring strict parliamentary oversight of international agreements.

ALDE entirely conflicts the issue's failure to mandate a Commission structure capable of driving supranational integration, contradicting Verhofstadt's demand for a "real driving force behind European Union"  
ALDE rejects the issue's procedural focus as incompatible with Wallis' insistence on Parliament being a "true legislative partner" rather than a mere "dimension" in EU governance  
ALDE condemns the issue's silence on creating binding socio-economic governance structures, directly conflicting with Lambsdorff's call for "strong Europe inside and out" through economic union  
ALDE opposes the issue's acceptance of portfolio overlaps in energy policy as undermining Vălean's requirement for "cohesive approach to global energy challenges" through unified leadership  
ALDE rejects the legal ambiguity tolerance in Commissioner nominations as incompatible with Ek's warning that imbalanced portfolios threaten "sustainable economic growth" in EU2020 strategy

ECR strongly promotes the issue’s demands for enhanced scrutiny of Commissioners’ qualifications, aligning with their reform agenda to reduce bureaucratic overreach and ensure merit-based appointments.  
ECR endorses the call for separate integrity hearings as critical to addressing public distrust, reflecting their longstanding commitment to accountability in EU governance.  
ECR proposes amending the approval process to require individual Parliamentary votes on each Commissioner-designate, converting the current “take it or leave it” approach into a mechanism for rigorous quality control.  
ECR highlights the unresolved energy security coordination between portfolios as an area requiring immediate clarification, reinforcing the issue’s emphasis on coherent crisis management frameworks.  
ECR applauds the focus on legal adjustments to prevent procedural delays, consistent with their manifesto’s priority of institutional transparency and mandate discipline.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the process of nominating and assigning portfolios to Commissioners, expressing dissatisfaction with the lack of transparency and consistency in candidate evaluations. It criticized the "take it or leave it" approach limiting meaningful scrutiny of individual qualifications and highlighted inadequate performances by nominees during hearings, including evasive answers and irrelevant policy promises. The resolution emphasized unresolved issues such as energy security and overlapping responsibilities between portfolios, particularly in transport, state aid, and the Galileo project, urging coherent coordination. It called for separate open hearings to address personal integrity concerns and noted legal ambiguities arising from the delayed nomination process, which allowed previous Commissioners to act beyond their mandate. While acknowledging confidence in the Commission President, Parliament demanded clarifications on policy coherence and legal adjustments to prevent future procedural delays, instructing the resolution’s transmission to EU institutions for action.

title: Revision of the Treaties – Transitional measures concerning the composition of the European Parliament: REPORT on the draft protocol amending Protocol No 36 on transitional provisions concerning the composition of the European Parliament for the rest of the 2009-2014 parliamentary term: the European Parliament’s opinion (Article 48(3) of the EU Treaty)
background: The Lisbon Treaty's entry into force (1 December 2009) altered European Parliament seat allocations from 736 (Nice Treaty) to 751 MEPs. The 2009 elections occurred under Nice rules, creating a discrepancy. Protocol No. 36 required adjustment to temporarily accommodate 18 additional MEPs from 12 states without mid-term reductions. The Parliament will discuss amending Protocol No. 36 to enable transitional composition measures for the 2009-2014 parliamentary term.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the immediate seating of all 18 additional MEPs through direct elections, aligning with their commitment to democratic legitimacy and institutional balance.  
EPP applauds the insistence on simultaneous integration of new Members to preserve fair national representation, reflecting their principle of equal citizenship across the Union.  
EPP urges accelerated ratification of Protocol No 36 amendments while maintaining opposition to national parliamentary appointments, reinforcing their dedication to direct voter mandates.  
EPP accepts the exceptional intergovernmental conference mechanism as a pragmatic solution but emphasizes this must not circumvent future convention processes for Treaty changes.  
EPP proposes harmonizing Member States' electoral procedures to prevent similar transitional delays, enhancing Lisbon Treaty implementation without opposing the issue's core timeline.

GREEN_EFA rejects fundamentally the acceptance of appointed Members from national legislatures as a violation of direct universal suffrage principles enshrined in EU treaties.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the Council’s endorsement of France’s indirect election method, which undermines Parliament’s democratic legitimacy and citizens’ electoral rights.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s failure to enforce Treaty compliance, particularly Article 14(3) TEU requiring direct elections, creating an undemocratic precedent.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal’s incompatibility with their core principle that MEP legitimacy derives solely from citizen mandates, not governmental appointments.  
GREEN_EFA asserts that seating parliamentarians chosen by national assemblies constitutes an institutional betrayal of European electoral sovereignty.

SD strongly promotes the issue's mandate for direct elections of all 18 additional MEPs, aligning with their commitment to democratic legitimacy and the 1976 Act on universal suffrage.  
SD applauds the urgency in seating duly elected representatives from 12 Member States, emphasizing that delayed implementation undermines institutional balance and citizen representation.  
SD urges expedited ratification processes to resolve France's procedural delays while maintaining the principle that all new Members must be directly elected rather than appointed through national parliaments.  
SD endorses the exceptional use of an intergovernmental conference for transitional measures but stresses this must not set precedents that bypass future Convention requirements for treaty changes.  
SD proposes establishing clear timelines in Protocol No 36 amendments to prevent prolonged uncertainty for incoming MEPs, addressing both institutional efficiency and individual preparedness.

GUE_NGL completely disputes any protocol enabling unelected MEPs, as this violates core democratic principles of direct representation  
GUE_NGL rejects transitional measures allowing appointed parliamentarians, directly contradicting Treaty requirements for elections under the 1976 Act  
This proposal dangerously undermines legitimacy by permitting non-elected members, despite 2007 precedents requiring immediate elections for new accession states  
The issue's tolerance for intergovernmental negotiations conflicts with GUE_NGL's absolute stance against indirect selection mechanisms  
GUE_NGL condemns the Council's failure to ensure simultaneous direct elections across all member states as required by Lisbon Treaty obligations

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the implementation of the Lisbon Treaty’s provisions on its composition, emphasizing the need to adjust the number of Members (MEPs) from 736 under the Nice Treaty to 751 as stipulated by the Lisbon Treaty. It noted that the 2009 elections were held under the Nice framework, resulting in 736 MEPs, but the Lisbon Treaty’s entry into force on 1 December 2009 necessitated adding 18 MEPs from 12 Member States, temporarily increasing the total to 754 until the end of the 2009-2014 term. This temporary overage required amending Protocol No 36 to accommodate transitional measures. The Parliament stressed that all 18 additional MEPs must take their seats simultaneously to preserve institutional balance, urging Member States to expedite their election processes. It criticized the Council’s delay in enabling the timely seating of these MEPs and opposed indirect election via national parliaments, favoring direct elections under the 1976 Act. While reluctantly accepting an intergovernmental conference to address transitional measures, it insisted these must be exceptional and not set precedents. The resolution also highlighted the need for future decisions on Parliament’s composition to account for potential new Member States and instructed its President to communicate the resolution to relevant EU institutions and national parliaments.

title: Commissioner hearings: lessons to be taken from the 2014 process: REPORT on procedures and practices regarding Commissioner hearings, lessons to be taken from the 2014 process
background: Following the 2014 European Commission hearings, concerns emerged over nomination timelines, gender representation in candidate selections, financial interest disclosures, and hearing procedures under EU treaties and prior parliamentary resolutions. The Parliament will discuss optimizing Commissioner-designate evaluation processes, focusing on procedures for enhancing transparency, gender balance, and accountability.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely supports the issue’s call for Member States to propose gender-balanced candidate lists, perfectly aligning with EPP’s longstanding commitment to institutional reform and equality in EU leadership.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the proposal to empower the Commission President to select from diverse professional profiles, reflecting their priority of maximizing competence in the College of Commissioners.  
EPP emphasizes structural reform of the nomination process as critical to achieving democratic legitimacy, a principle central to their governance agenda.  
EPP applauds the issue’s focus on rigorous scrutiny during hearings, which advances their transparency objectives and ensures accountability to citizens.  
EPP recognizes enhanced public engagement through social media as vital to reinforcing citizen trust, consistent with their digital democracy initiatives.

EFDD partly agrees the enhanced scrutiny mechanisms for hearings but requests revisions to mandate direct public accountability mechanisms for unelected Commissioners.  
EFDD fundamentally disputes the issue’s failure to address the undemocratic structure of Commissioner appointments, inconsistent with their stance that "the people have no say."  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as requiring Member States to submit multiple candidates for public vote, a prerequisite for meaningful accountability.  
EFDD highlights structural contradictions in prioritizing gender parity while retaining a system where "larger Member States predominantly proposed male candidates" without electoral checks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of enhancing democratic legitimacy and transparency through public hearings of Commissioners-designate, emphasizing their role in assessing candidates' qualifications, priorities, and suitability for their portfolios. The resolution proposed procedural improvements, including setting deadlines for Member States to nominate candidates, expanding written questionnaires to seven questions, allowing immediate follow-up questions to improve scrutiny, and extending hearings for Vice-Presidents beyond three hours due to their broader responsibilities. It stressed the need to strengthen financial transparency by requiring Commissioners-designate to disclose family members’ interests and broadening the Committee on Legal Affairs’ scrutiny to identify conflicts of interest. The resolution highlighted the 2014 hearings’ increased public engagement via social media and urged leveraging such platforms to involve citizens. It addressed structural challenges, such as aligning portfolios with parliamentary committees’ remits and ensuring fair evaluation processes, including replacement candidates’ hearings under equal conditions. Specific concerns were raised about last-minute portfolio changes, notably in Transport, which disrupted fair assessment. The Parliament also advocated periodic reviews of Commissioners’ post-appointment performance and stricter adherence to deadlines for publishing evaluation statements within 24 hours after hearings. Overall, the resolution sought to institutionalize gender parity, enhance accountability, and improve the rigor and inclusivity of the Commission approval process.

title: Amendments to Parliament's Rules of Procedure: REPORT on amendments to Parliament’s Rules of Procedure affectingChapters 1 and 4 of Title I; Chapter 3 of Title V; Chapters 4 and 5 of Title VII; Chapter 1 of Title VIII; Title XII; Title XIV and Annex II

resolution: The European Parliament raised significant concerns over the Council and Commission’s obstruction of efforts to adopt a regulation strengthening its investigative powers under Article 226 TFEU, which mandates a special legislative procedure requiring their consent. Despite over four years of informal negotiations, working documents, and legal consultations between the institutions’ services, the Council and Commission refused to engage in formal political discussions to resolve key disagreements, including institutional resistance to granting Parliament robust inquiry tools such as witness summons and document access. The resolution criticized this as a breach of sincere interinstitutional cooperation (Article 13(2) TEU) and democratic accountability, emphasizing Parliament’s constitutional role in overseeing the executive. It highlighted lessons from recent inquiry committees (PANA on financial crimes and EMIS on emissions fraud), which underscored the need for updated investigative rules. Parliament urged its President to escalate the issue to EU leaders, proposed legal action via the Court of Justice to enforce cooperation obligations, and called on political parties and *Spitzenkandidaten* to publicly support the revised regulation. The resolution also stressed that the current procedural framework under Article 226 TFEU does not oblige the Council and Commission to negotiate, but Parliament insisted they resume talks based on a revised proposal reflecting legal consultations and practical experience, while invoking the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making to demand structured negotiations. The text was forwarded to EU institutions and national parliaments to reinforce accountability demands.

The resolution urged EU institutions and member states to prioritize e-government services, open data, and pilot projects like crowdsourcing, while promoting gender equality in ICT and political processes. It called for a European Charter of Internet Rights to safeguard net neutrality, privacy, and freedom of expression, and highlighted the need for critical media literacy to counter misinformation. title: European Citizens' Initiative: REPORT on the European Citizens’ Initiative

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the implementation challenges and shortcomings of the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI), a participatory democracy tool enabling citizens to propose legislation by collecting one million signatures from at least seven Member States. Despite over six million citizens participating in 51 initiatives since 2012, only three—Right2Water, One of Us, and Stop Vivisection—were deemed admissible, with six rejected initiatives challenged in court, highlighting procedural and legal barriers. Key issues included complex data requirements, lack of user-friendly IT tools, insufficient public awareness, and rigid admissibility checks by the Commission, which faced criticism for potential conflicts of interest. The resolution called for revising Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 to simplify processes, lower the minimum participation age to 16, standardize data collection (removing personal ID requirements), extend the 12-month signature period, and decouple registration from the collection start date. It urged enhanced support through free translation, a centralized online platform, financial assistance, and improved Commission guidance to organizers. The Parliament emphasized the need for transparency, institutional accountability, and public hearings, while advocating for clearer rejection reasoning, partial registration of initiatives, and post-submission legislative follow-up within 12 months. Strengthening interinstitutional cooperation, leveraging digital tools, and addressing liability concerns for organizers were also prioritized to revitalize the ECI’s role in bridging citizens and EU policymaking.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the Council of the EU’s lack of transparency in legislative processes, particularly in its preparatory bodies like Coreper and over 150 working groups, which often operate behind closed doors, undermining democratic accountability. It criticized the Council’s failure to proactively publish legislative documents, reliance on the unjustified ‘LIMITE’ classification to restrict access, and refusal to systematically record or disclose Member States’ positions, hindering public scrutiny and enabling governments to evade responsibility for EU decisions. The resolution endorsed the European Ombudsman’s findings of maladministration and urged the Council to implement recommendations, including public access to meetings via live-streaming, publishing minutes, aligning practices with CJEU rulings, and ending opaque consensus-based decision-making instead of using qualified majority voting. It highlighted the imbalance in transparency between Parliament’s open procedures and the Council’s secretive practices, stressing the need for equivalent standards to combat misinformation and strengthen public trust, especially ahead of the 2019 elections. The Parliament also demanded formalizing informal bodies like the Eurogroup under EU transparency rules, transforming the Council into a transparent legislative chamber, and ensuring trilogues adhere to public mandates and document disclosure. It emphasized that systemic opacity in the Council contradicts Treaty obligations and democratic principles, eroding citizen confidence in the EU.

resolution: The European Parliament raised amendments to its Rules of Procedure to enhance legislative efficiency, transparency, and accountability, aligning with the 2016 Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making. Key changes included mandating the Secretary-General to adapt IT systems for tracking written questions, deleting Rule 106(4) once regulatory scrutiny procedures are phased out, and revising the Code of Conduct for legislative negotiations. Transparency measures required Members to update financial interest declarations within six months, prohibited paid lobbying roles, introduced stricter verification of declarations, and mandated former MEPs to inform Parliament of new lobbying positions. Lobbying rules were tightened, including badge removal for non-compliance and banning entourage badges for lobbying. Procedural reforms streamlined voting sequences, limited written questions to 20 per MEP every three months (addressing over 60,000 annual submissions), capped motions for resolutions to one per member monthly, restricted roll-call votes to 100 per group per session, and proposed abolishing written declarations or requiring 40 MEPs from three groups to table them. Thresholds for initiatives were set at one-twentieth, one-tenth, or one-fifth of Parliament’s membership. Intergroups were required to operate transparently, and committees gained authority to accelerate priority legislation. The Commission was obligated to respond to parliamentary initiatives within three months or face committee scrutiny, and withdrawals of proposals required consultation with Parliament. Amendments entered force at the next session, except Rule 212(2) on delegations, effective after the 2019 elections.

It grants the Ombudsman authority to conduct own-initiative inquiries to address systemic issues, follow up on compliance with recommendations, and submit annual reports to Parliament assessing institutional compliance and resource adequacy. Complaints must be filed within three years of the complainant becoming aware of the issue, after exhausting administrative remedies, and can remain confidential. The Ombudsman has broad access to information, including classified documents, subject to confidentiality agreements, and must notify relevant authorities (e.g., the European Public Prosecutor’s Office) of potential criminal matters while respecting due process rights. Institutions are required to respond to inquiries within three months (extendable by two months) and cooperate fully, with non-compliance reported to Parliament. The Ombudsman’s independence is safeguarded through appointment by Parliament for the parliamentary term, with qualifications mirroring judicial standards, and a budget ensuring operational autonomy. resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and recommendations regarding the use of enhanced cooperation in the EU, emphasizing its role as a last-resort mechanism under Article 20 TEU to advance integration when unanimity cannot be achieved. It highlighted that enhanced cooperation, requiring at least nine Member States, has been underutilized but proven effective in areas like divorce law, property regimes (18 participating states as of 2019), the European Patent, and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO), which involves 22 Member States and aims to combat EU budget fraud by late 2020. The resolution noted challenges, including lengthy procedures due to unclear timelines, lack of operational guidelines, and reliance on intergovernmental agreements outside EU frameworks (e.g., the Fiscal Compact), which undermine legal consistency and democratic scrutiny. It urged activating Article 333 TFEU to switch from unanimity to qualified majority voting (QMV) post-authorization, enhancing parliamentary oversight via stronger roles for the European Parliament and national/regional legislatures, and clarifying rules for Member State withdrawal or expulsion. The resolution called for EU budget alignment with enhanced cooperation costs, CJEU jurisdiction, and a Commission unit to streamline coordination. It stressed integrating enhanced cooperation into the *acquis communautaire* and urged Treaty revisions to address gaps, including sub-national entities’ roles. Specific to the EPPO, Parliament urged non-participating states to join, emphasized cooperation with OLAF and Eurojust, and supported potential mandate expansion to counter-terrorism. Overall, the resolution advocated preserving the EU’s institutional framework while using enhanced cooperation pragmatically to overcome deadlocks, ensuring transparency, inclusivity, and legal coherence.

It called for technical adjustments to extend scrutiny timelines and urged national parliaments to engage more proactively in political dialogue, including submitting constructive proposals to the Commission. It endorsed initiatives like an annual "European Week" to foster public debate involving MEPs, Commissioners, and national MPs, alongside enhanced interparliamentary cooperation in security, defense, and economic governance, including aligning the European Semester with national budgetary processes. The Parliament rejected joint parliamentary decision-making bodies to preserve accountability but encouraged committee-level collaboration and exchanges of best practices. It stressed the importance of proportional representation of political minorities in national parliamentary opinions and urged reforms to strengthen parliamentary oversight of EU trade agreements and fiscal policies, while opposing a "red card" procedure as incompatible with current treaty frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for comprehensive electoral reforms to enhance the democratic legitimacy, transparency, and transnational dimension of EU elections, proposing measures to transform the 2024 elections into a unified European process. Key proposals include establishing a **Union-wide constituency** with **28 seats** elected via transnational lists headed by lead candidates for Commission President, aiming to strengthen the European political space and link votes to EU-level outcomes. The resolution emphasizes harmonizing electoral standards, such as setting a **minimum voting age of 16** (while respecting existing constitutional norms), ensuring gender equality through zipped lists or quotas, and improving accessibility for persons with disabilities—noting that **12 Member States** restrict polling station flexibility for disabled voters. It calls for removing barriers to minority representation, citing that only **2.8% of MEPs** (20 out of 705) identify as minorities, and advocates exemptions from electoral thresholds for minority parties. The Parliament highlights the **2019 elections’ 50.6% turnout**—the highest in 20 years—as evidence of growing citizen engagement on issues like climate, recovery, and rule of law, urging enhanced visibility for European political parties and their programs. Reforms also target logistical improvements: a **common electoral roll deadline** (14 weeks pre-election), measures against double voting, and a **European Electoral Authority** to oversee standards, manage transnational lists, and resolve disputes. The resolution stresses the lead candidate process’s formalization, youth inclusion via the 2022 Year of Youth, and safeguards against foreign interference, while promoting postal and accessible voting options. It aligns with the Conference on the Future of Europe’s recommendations and seeks to deepen ties between voters and EU institutions through transparent candidate selection, media engagement, and alignment of campaign financing with revised EU regulations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the necessity to amend its Rules of Procedure to address gaps exposed by the COVID-19 pandemic, ensuring uninterrupted parliamentary functions during extraordinary circumstances. title: European Parliament's position on the Conference on the Future of Europe: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the European Parliament’s position on the Conference on the Future of Europe | B9-0036/2020 | European Parliament
background: Increased EU citizen engagement in 2019 elections, post-Lisbon Treaty institutional challenges, and evolving geopolitical pressures prompted calls for structured dialogue on EU reform. The Parliament will discuss organizing a participatory process to address governance, policy priorities, and democratic legitimacy through a Conference on the Future of Europe.

SD endorses the binding follow-up mechanism requiring legislative proposals, consistent with their demand for "concrete results not consultations" in the 2019 electoral program.

GREEN_EFA entirely upholds the citizen-driven design of Citizens' Agoras as perfectly aligning with their federalist vision of pan-European participatory democracy.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on treaty changes to enable EU-wide climate action and tax justice, mirroring Daniel Freund's call for "tools to address major challenges."  
GREEN_EFA entirely upholds the Youth Agoras and degressive proportionality as critical for realizing Christian Allard's vision of inclusive European citizenship beyond current member states.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with transparency mechanisms like web-streamed meetings, operationalizing Scott Ainslie's demand to amplify citizen voices over corporate lobbyists.  
GREEN_EFA entirely upholds binding follow-up through treaty revisions, actualizing Patrick Breyer's vision of citizens "deciding the EU they want" via constitutional conventions.

ECR opposes the exclusionary drafting process that barred two political groups from substantive input, contradicting principles of democratic pluralism enshrined in EU governance.  
ECR firmly challenges with the predetermined federalist agenda embedded in the issue's structure, viewing transnational Spitzenkandidat processes as undermining national sovereignty.  
ECR condemns the proposal's failure to prioritize subsidiarity, demanding explicit guarantees against EU overreach into member states' competencies like labor policies.

ID opposes the issue's citizen engagement mechanisms for excluding nationalist perspectives, evidenced by Laura Huhtasaari's condemnation of sidelining ID-aligned voter concerns about EU overreach.  
The proposal fails to address core ID priorities like migration control and economic nationalism, with Mara Bizzotto denouncing its silence on border security and protectionist trade measures as "detached from citizens' realities".  
ID condemns the climate-focused agenda as a pretext for centralized taxation, aligning with Harald Vilimsky's critique of CO2 fees disproportionately harming national industries and households.  
The issue's treaty change ambitions directly contradict Jordan Bardella's demand for "cooperation between sovereign nations" rather than supranational governance structures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for a comprehensive, citizen-driven Conference on the Future of Europe to address evolving challenges and strengthen EU governance, proposing a two-year process starting on 9 May 2020 and concluding by summer 2022. Emphasizing citizen engagement, the resolution advocates a bottom-up approach through thematic Citizens’ Agoras (comprising 200-300 participants per session, with at least three from each Member State, selected via degressive proportionality) and Youth Agoras (ages 16-25), ensuring geographic, gender, age, and socio-economic diversity. Key policy priorities include EU values, climate crisis, digital transformation, security, and institutional reforms, informed by Eurobarometer surveys. The Conference Plenary, involving 135 MEPs, 27 Council ministers, national parliamentarians, and EU bodies, would convene twice yearly, with outcomes aiming for consensus or majority agreement. Governance would be led by a gender-balanced Steering Committee (representing Parliament, Council, and Commission) and an Executive Coordination Board, supported by a multilingual secretariat. The resolution stresses transparency through web-streamed meetings, public documents, and inclusive communication tools, while urging follow-up actions, including legislative proposals or treaty changes. Youth participation, reimbursement for citizen attendees, and involvement of candidate countries were highlighted as critical to ensuring lasting impact and legitimacy.

title: European Parliament’s Scrutiny on the ongoing assessment by the Commission and the Council of the national recovery and resilience plans: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the views of Parliament on the ongoing assessment by the Commission and the Council of the national recovery and resilience plans | RC-B9-0331/2021 | European Parliament

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) in fostering economic, social, and territorial cohesion, supporting the green and digital transitions, and mitigating the COVID-19 pandemic’s impacts. It insisted on strict monitoring of milestones, transparent reporting, and visibility of EU funding, underscoring the need for accountability in achieving climate neutrality, digital resilience, and upward social convergence.

title: Parliament’s right of initiative: REPORT on Parliament’s right of initiative | A9-0142/2022 | European Parliament

The Conference on the Future of Europe emphasized institutional reform and democratic legitimacy. The Parliament will discuss expanding its role in initiating EU legislation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about its lack of a general direct right of legislative initiative despite being the EU’s only directly elected institution, emphasizing that the Commission holds a near-monopoly under Article 17(2) TEU. It highlighted its limited success under Article 225 TFEU, where only one-third of its legislative initiatives up to 2019 resulted in Commission proposals, and criticized the Commission’s inconsistent follow-up and the Council’s failure to act on key issues like rule of law enforcement, notably regarding Hungary and the unimplemented EU mechanism on democracy. The resolution called for Treaty revisions to grant Parliament a direct right of initiative, particularly in policy areas where it co-legislates, and urged leveraging the Conference on the Future of Europe to strengthen democratic legitimacy. It stressed the need to extend the ordinary legislative procedure, enhance transparency in Council initiatives under Article 241 TFEU, and improve interinstitutional cooperation, citing the 2010 Framework Agreement and the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making. The Parliament also noted procedural gaps, such as three Member States not ratifying the 2018 EU electoral law reform and the Council’s refusal to negotiate on Parliament’s right of inquiry. It welcomed the Commission’s recent commitment to respond to Article 225 requests with legislative proposals but demanded stricter deadlines, better impact assessments, and clearer links between Parliament’s initiatives and subsequent legislation. The resolution reiterated the urgency of addressing democratic deficits, empowering citizens through European Citizens’ Initiatives, and ensuring institutional accountability to uphold EU values.

title: Proposal for an Interinstitutional Agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management: REPORT on conclusion of an Interinstitutional Agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management, as well as on new own resources, including a roadmap towards the introduction of new own resources | A9-0261/2020 | European Parliament
background: Following the 2013 Interinstitutional Agreement's expiration and the establishment of the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework, EU institutions negotiated a renewed budgetary pact amid COVID-19 recovery efforts and climate commitments under the Paris Agreement. The Parliament will discuss an interinstitutional agreement on budgetary discipline, financial cooperation, and new revenue mechanisms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of a renewed Interinstitutional Agreement (IIA) on budgetary discipline, cooperation, and sound financial management for the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), alongside the European Recovery Instrument (Next Generation EU/NGEU). The agreement introduces a roadmap for new own resources, including potential levies linked to sustainability and digitalization, to cover repayment costs of the €750 billion NGEU debt while ensuring sufficient revenue ceilings and adherence to budgetary discipline under Article 310 TFEU. It mandates monitoring of climate and biodiversity spending, with 30% of the EU budget and NGEU expenditures allocated to climate objectives, a biodiversity spending target of 7.5% by 2024 rising to 10% in 2026-2027, and gender equality and Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) tracking. Enhanced budgetary scrutiny of NGEU funds includes institutional cooperation on governance, transparency in project selection for the Recovery and Resilience Facility, and involvement of regional authorities to ensure equitable recovery. The IIA strengthens data standardization for tracking beneficiaries, improves transparency in budgetary programming, and safeguards special instruments like the Brexit Adjustment Reserve and Flexibility Instrument. It replaces the 2013 Interinstitutional Agreement, operationalizes treaty-based cooperation during MFF negotiations, and integrates rule-of-law conditionality for budget protection, reflecting commitments to the Paris Agreement and COVID-19 recovery priorities.

The funding restrictions and activity limitations overlook critical aspects of political pluralism by privileging Eurocentric federalism over national democratic mandates.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and proposed reforms to enhance the transparency, efficiency, and democratic role of European political parties and foundations under Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1141/2014. It emphasized the need for these entities to promote EU values, foster citizen engagement, and strengthen the European public sphere, while addressing obstacles such as administrative burdens, restrictive funding rules, and insufficient visibility. Key issues included inadequate compliance with logo display requirements by national member parties (only 15% met standards), overly narrow revenue categories, and the need to lower the co-financing rate for parties from 10% to 5% to align with foundations. The resolution advocated allowing financing of EU-related referendum campaigns, expanding permissible activities, and revising membership criteria to include parties from non-EU European countries and direct citizen participation. It called for harmonizing rules to reduce legal uncertainty, abolishing redundant financial reporting standards (e.g., International Financial Reporting Standards), and extending carry-over periods for foundations to N+1. Transparency measures included stricter scrutiny of donations exceeding €3,000, public disclosure of financial statements, and preventing circumvention of donation limits by 2027. The Parliament urged strengthening the Authority’s capacity to enforce compliance with EU values, proposed vote-based funding to boost electoral engagement, and demanded a single legal framework to consolidate rules on registration, financing, and governance. It also highlighted the need for clearer EU legal status for parties to avoid classification as foreign entities under national laws and emphasized democratic internal structures aligned with Article 2 TEU values. The Commission was urged to incorporate these proposals in its upcoming legislative review to enhance accountability, inclusivity, and the pan-European political landscape.

title: Stocktaking of European elections: REPORT on stocktaking of European elections | A9-0211/2020 | European Parliament
background: The 2019 European elections recorded a 50.66% turnout, the highest in 20 years, with increased youth participation but persistent disparities in voter accessibility, gender representation, and cross-border electoral rules. The Parliament will discuss evaluating electoral procedures and potential reforms to strengthen democratic engagement and EU political integration.

stances.stance:

SD strongly advocates embedding the Conference on the Future of Europe's deliberations into electoral reform processes, ensuring citizen-led proposals inform transnational voting mechanisms.  
SD fundamentally accepts harmonized accessibility standards for marginalized groups, advancing S&D's mandate to eliminate legal and practical barriers to universal suffrage.

GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing the issue by explicitly addressing cases of political rights violations, such as the disenfranchisement of elected MEPs, to strengthen democratic accountability.

ECR opposes the Spitzenkandidaten process, citing its failure in 2019 as undemocratic and a breach of the Council’s treaty-mandated role in selecting the Commission President.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined key priorities following the 2019 European elections, noting a 50.66% voter turnout—the highest in 20 years—driven by youth engagement (over 50% motivated by climate urgency and civic duty) but marked by disparities among Member States and high abstention rates. It highlighted the need to address barriers for marginalized groups, including 800,000 citizens with disabilities disenfranchised by national laws and 700,000 homeless people facing voting access challenges. Gender representation improved to 41% women MEPs, though imbalances persist across states. The resolution criticized the failure of the Spitzenkandidaten process to secure the Commission Presidency, urging reforms by 2024 to enhance transparency and voter awareness, alongside proposals for transnational lists, harmonized electoral rules (including lowering the voting age to 16), and a unified European electoral law. It called for combating foreign interference and disinformation through increased funding, media literacy, and an independent ethics body, while advocating for a European Electoral Authority to oversee electoral integrity. The Parliament emphasized strengthening European political parties via campaign finance transparency, visibility on ballots, and pan-European debates, and endorsed the Conference on the Future of Europe to address institutional reforms, such as transforming the Council into a legislative chamber. Additional measures included improving accessibility for Roma communities, harmonizing voter registration deadlines, and ensuring media coverage of EU issues to reinforce democratic engagement.

title: The UK’s withdrawal from the EU: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the state of play of the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union | B9-0038/2019 | European Parliament
background: The UK triggered Article 50 TEU in March 2017 to leave the EU, initiating withdrawal negotiations. Ratification challenges persisted for the endorsed 2018 Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration, with multiple extensions granted to avoid no-deal Brexit. Institutional preparedness and unresolved Irish border arrangements remained critical. The Parliament will discuss the UK's withdrawal process status and implications.

stances.stance:
EPP fully approves the issue's emphasis on the Withdrawal Agreement as the only viable framework to protect citizens' rights and maintain peace in Ireland, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to European unity and legal certainty.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's insistence on maintaining the backstop mechanism, recognizing it as essential to preserve the Good Friday Agreement and prevent economic fragmentation across Ireland.  
EPP fully supports the call for rigorous administrative reforms to the UK's Settlement Scheme, emphasizing the need to convert pre-settled status into permanent protections for all eligible EU citizens.  
EPP strongly affirms the issue's conditional approach to Article 50 extensions, requiring concrete democratic purposes like elections or referendums to justify prolonging negotiations.  
EPP endorses the issue's rejection of post-no-deal agreements lacking EU standards safeguards, upholding EPP's principle that future relations must maintain regulatory parity and level playing field commitments.
